questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given an intravenous drug, and later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following can be used to treat him?
questions.solution:
Benzhexol should be used in the management of this patient. The development of abnormal movements following an anti-emetic injection suggests that the antiemetic used in this case is probably metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist used as a prokinetic and anti-emetic agent. It can produce extrapyramidal side effects and dystonia is seen acutely following intravenous injections. Anticholinergics like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are used in the management of these side effects. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting anticholinergic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

Extrapyramidal side effects of metoclopramide are commonly seen in children and young adults with higher doses. Acute dystonia occurs after intravenous administration, while parkinsonian-like symptoms develop weeks after therapy. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with anticholinergics or antihistaminics. Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment.

Other adverse effects:

It can cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Option A: Hyoscine (scopolamine): It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the management of motion sickness and vomiting.

Option B: Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist used in the management of various allergy-related conditions like allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis, urticaria, etc.

Option C: Levodopa is the precursor of dopamine and it is given in combination with carbidopa for the management of parkinsonism.

questions.text: A female patient in normal labor is being administered care with active management of the third stage of labor. What is the dose of misoprostol that you would administer orally for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
600 micrograms of misoprostol administered orally at delivery is effective for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).  

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E 1 analog that has been used for the prevention and treatment of uterine atony and PPH.   

Although contrasting evidence about its effectiveness is present, it is to be used at a dose of 600 micrograms when used orally.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a mass on his jaw, containing draining sinuses with purulent discharge. The culture of the discharge from the sinus grew colonies, which are shown in the image given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing molar tooth colonies that are characteristic of actinomyces species. The given clinical scenario describes a lumpy jaw seen in cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection caused by Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.

The image given below shows cervicofacial actinomycosis.

The image given below shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by examination of the pus from sinuses, sputum, or tissue specimens for sulfur granules. These granules are yellow, hard, lobulated, and made of tissue and bacterial filaments. Gram staining shows filamentous gram-positive bacteria.

Specimens should be cultured anaerobically on appropriate media such as chocolate blood agar, brain heart infusion broth, and brucella blood agar with hemin and vitamin K1. They may form molar-tooth colonies on agar and grows as clumps within the broth. Actinomyces species are mostly facultative anaerobes. 

Treatment is with IV penicillin for 2-6 weeks followed by oral therapy with penicillin or amoxicillin for serious infections.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptococcus usually manifests as meningitis with headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. In addition, there may be lesions in the skin, lungs, or other organs. Cryptococcus produces whitish mucoid colonies. On microscopy, spherical budding yeast cells with a thick capsule are seen.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis usually manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce nonhemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Klebsiella is a gram-negative, encapsulated, non-motile bacterium. It can cause pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin and wound infections. It produces a very viscous, mucoid growth when cultured on ordinary media. On MacConkey agar, they grow as lactose-forming colonies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent pregnancy losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions, all of them at <10 weeks of gestational age, and has a history of deep vein thrombosis. The presence of which of the following antibodies is not included in the laboratory criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
The antinuclear antibody is not included in the laboratory criteria for the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

Recurrent pregnancy loss is a term used for three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions of the fetus before 20 weeks of gestation. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. The antiphospholipid antibodies cause inflammation, thrombosis, and abnormal placentation leading to recurrent miscarriage, usually before 10 weeks of gestation. 

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion and must be positive on 2 or more occasions 12 weeks apart.

  • Clinical criteria
    • Obstetric
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular: one or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue 
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Treatment:

  • Low-dose aspirin (60-80 mg/day)
  • Unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin

 These drugs are started at the time of diagnosis and are given until 6 weeks postpartum.

questions.text:
A patient with coronary artery disease who does not tolerate 1st line anti-anginal drugs is prescribed trimetazidine. How would you classify this drug according to its mechanism of action?

pFOX - partial fatty acid oxidation
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor.

Trimetazidine partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the heart by inhibiting the last enzyme in the beta-oxidation pathway. This causes a shift in heart metabolism to use glucose. Since oxygen required is lesser in glucose metabolism, it is believed to be helpful in ischemia by decreasing the oxygen demand of the heart.

It is used as a second-line anti-anginal drug in case of stable angina when 1st line agents are not tolerated.

Side effects include nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal upset. It can also cause hepatic enzyme elevation and thrombocytopenia.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman who underwent D&C for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with frequent abdominal pain and distension. Her beta hCG levels were persistently elevated. Further investigations revealed a tumor confined to the uterus with no metastasis. What is the appropriate management in this case?

D&C- Dilatation and curettage
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Among the given options, the most appropriate treatment for a woman is methotrexate with folinic acid.

The low-risk status of this patient is indicated by the WHO prognostic score of 1 in this case (age <40 years = 0, antecedent molar pregnancy = 0, the interval of 6 months = 1, no metastatic lesions = 0). 

Treatment of GTN:

  • Low-risk GTN (score 0-6): Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate (MTX) or dactinomycin (less commonly used). 
    • 50 mg MTX is given IM on days 1, 3, 5, and 7, with folinic acid on alternate days 
  • High-risk GTN (score >7): Multi-agent chemotherapy, with or without adjuvant surgery or radiotherapy. The preferred multiple-agent regime is the EMACO regime:
    • Etoposide
    • Methotrexate
    • Dactinomycin (actinomycin D)
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Vincristine (Oncovin)

Scoring is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system, as adapted by FIGO. It is as follows.

Antecedent gestation Mole Abortion Term -
Interval in months <4 4-6 7-12 >12
Pretreatment serum hCG (IU/L) < 103 103 to < 104 104 to < 105 > 105
Largest tumor size (including the uterus) <3 3-4 ≥ 5  -
Site of metastases Lung Spleen, kidney GI tract Brain, liver
Number of metastases - 1-4 5-8 >8
Previously failed chemotherapy  - - single drug ≥ 2 drugs
  • Low-risk GTN: Score <=6
  • High-risk GTN: Score >=7

Gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) arise from an abnormal placenta and include partial and complete hydatidiform moles, as well as gestational trophoblastic neoplasias (GTN).

GTN includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT). They typically develop along with or after a molar pregnancy. Rarely, it may develop after live birth, miscarriage, or medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has hearing difficulty in his right ear, with frequent episodes of tinnitus. Further clinical examination shows a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image are diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. The rollover phenomenon is seen in this condition.

When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other options:

The recruitment phenomenon refers to abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

Diplacusis is the discordance of sounds in which a single auditory stimulus of a particular frequency is heard at different pitches in both ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds produce vertigo due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

The recruitment phenomenon, diplacusis, and Tullio phenomenon are all seen in Meniere's disease.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of gradually progressive swelling and pain over the upper portion of the tibia for the past 5-6 months. An x-ray of the affected area is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the radiograph showing an area of lucency with sclerotic borders, is suggestive of Brodie's abscess. An open biopsy with curettage is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. The organism mostly involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

Differential diagnosis: The clinical features and x-ray can mimic several other conditions.

  • Cystic tuberculosis
  • Eosinophilic granuloma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Investigations: 

  • WBC counts and blood cultures are usually normal.
  • ESR may be elevated in some cases. 
  • The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. 
  • MRI may be helpful in diagnosis.
  • Open biopsy with curettage is indicated if there is any doubt in the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months
  • Curettage is needed if the x-rays show no healing after conservative management.
  • Curettage is also done along with open biopsy in doubtful cases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with muscle weakness, abnormal tingling sensation over the face, and pain and swelling over the knee joint for 3 months. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Investigations show hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria with metabolic alkalosis. His x-ray knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with muscle weakness, paresthesia over the face, hypotension, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, metabolic alkalosis, and x-ray knee showing chondrocalcinosis as punctate density on the cartilage are suggestive of Gitelman's syndrome. 

Gitelman's syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. It occurs due to a mutation of Na+-Cl– co-transporter (NCCT) in the distal tubule. 

NCCT helps in the absorption of sodium and chloride ions from the lumen of the distal tubule. In Gitelman's syndrome, due to the loss of function of NCCT, there will be increased sodium and chloride delivery to collecting duct and volume retraction. This results in increased renin and aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone act on epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct causing increased reabsorption of sodium and increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Downregulation of magnesium-permeable channels in Gitelman syndrome leads to urinary loss of magnesium resulting in hypomagnesemia.

There is increased passive reabsorption of calcium in the proximal convoluted tubule in Gitelman syndrome resulting in hypocalciuria. 

Hypomagnesemia impairs the function of calcitropic hormones and down-regulates the normal inverse association between ionized calcium, parathyroid hormone, and calcitriol. This results in reduced skeletal sensitivity of PTH and impaired intestinal calcium transport and explains the lack of hypercalcemia response to hypocalciuria. 

Low magnesium levels result in the reduction of pyrophosphate activity that could promote pyrophosphate crystallization in joints causing joint pains and chondrocalcinosis.

Even though patients present above the age of 6 years, the diagnosis in most cases is established during adulthood. Patients often present with signs of tetany, paresthesias, and chondrocalcinosis, as a result of hypomagnesemia and fatiguability. 

Hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia prolong the duration of the action potential of cardiomyocytes and consequently increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmia. 

Other options:

Option A: Bartter's syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl-  co-transporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Liddle's syndrome causes increased activation of epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) channels expressed on the apical membrane of principal cells of the collecting duct. It results in severe hypertension with hypokalemia.

Option D: Fanconi's syndrome occurs due to a defect in the proximal tubular function that prevents the absorption of electrolytes and other substances that are normally absorbed by the proximal tubule. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A histologist is studying the cut section of the umbilical cord given below. What is the adult derivative of the proximal part of the structure marked by an arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is an umbilical artery. Its proximal part forms the superior vesical artery in adults. 

The umbilical artery has the following fate:

  • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
  • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with loss of appetite, jaundice, and easy bruisability. He is a chronic alcohol user, and the following abnormality is noted on examination. What is the most likely cause of this nail change?
questions.solution:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia totalis. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of liver cirrhosis, which leads to hypoalbuminemia.

Leukonychia is an opaque whitish discoloration of the nail and is seen in the following conditions:

  • Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
  • Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
  • Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiforme, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye since morning. She also complains of pain on movement of the right eye for two days.  She gives a history of weakness in her right upper limb one month ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, the following finding is elicited. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis, and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis. The above image shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus-Gunn pupil) on the swinging flashlight test. On shining the torchlight to the normal eye, both the pupils constrict due to intact direct and indirect light reflexes to the stimulus carried by the normal optic nerve. On swinging and shining the torchlight to the diseased eye, both the pupils appear to dilate. This is due to the damage to the optic nerve carrying the afferent fibers in the diseased eye, resulting in the loss of direct and indirect light reflexes. This phenomenon is seen in cases of unilateral optic nerve damage, like in this patient's optic neuritis.

High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Other options:

Options B and C: Plasma exchange can be used for an acute relapse of MS but is not the first preferred treatment. It can be used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta Interferon can be used in relapsing MS to slow the attack rate and reduce disability. It is not suitable for an acute episode of optic myelitis.

Option D: Acyclovir is an antiviral and is not effective in the treatment of optic neuritis due to acute MS. 

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: A mother asks for LASIK surgery for the correction of her 15-year-old daughter's myopia. Which of the following is not an eligibility criterion for this procedure?

choices.text: Stable refraction for the past 1 year

questions.solution:
Age of 15 years is not a criterion for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age.

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser in individuals aged > 18 years who have a stable refractive error for 1 year. It is done in individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment. Corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus must be ruled out before this procedure.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Section A Section B
1. Granulosa cell tumor a. Schiller-Duval bodies
2. Endodermal sinus tumor b. Walthard cell nest
3. Brenner tumor c. Hobnail cell
4. Clear cell tumor d. Call–Exner bodies
questions.solution:
The correctly matched ovarian tumors with their pathological findings include:

Tumor type HPE finding
Granulosa cell tumor Call–Exner bodies
Endodermal sinus tumor Schiller-Duval bodies
Brenner tumor Walthard cell nest 
Clear cell tumor Hobnail cell

The images below show Call-Exner bodies, a pathognomic of granulosa cell tumor. Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material similar to immature follicles. Granulosa cells with pale, grooved, “coffee bean” nuclei are seen. 

The image below shows the Schiller-Duval body, which is pathognomic of the endodermal sinus tumor. Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumor. Walthard cell rests are benign clusters of epithelial cells resembling transitional cells.

The image below shows the hobnail cell, which is pathognomic of clear cell ovarian tumors. They are clear cells showing large dark nuclei protruding into the lumen.

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth. The pediatrician notes that the baby is not breathing, so she warms and dries the baby, clears the airway, and stimulates the baby. After 30 seconds, she notices that the heart rate is 88 beats/ minute and that the baby is still apneic. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the neonate has a heart rate of less than 100 beats/ minute, is not crying, and is apneic at 30 seconds of evaluation. Thus, according to the American Heart Association guidelines for newborn resuscitation, positive pressure ventilation should be started. 

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is the primary method of providing support for newborns who are apneic, have bradycardia, or have poor respiratory effort. It is successful in producing a response in most babies, clinically evident by an improvement in heart rate, the establishment of breathing, or crying. 

It may be initiated with air (21% oxygen) in term and late preterm newborns and up to 30% oxygen in preterm babies. They should be monitored using a pulse oximeter. 

Other options: 

Option A - Chest compressions should be started if the heart rate is less than 60 beats/ minute despite adequate PPV. The ratio is 3 compressions to 1 inflation using the 2 thumbs, encircling hands technique. It should be 30 inflations and 90 compressions per minute. 

Option B - IV epinephrine should be administered if the heart rate is less than 60 beats/ minute despite 60 seconds of chest compressions and adequate PPV. 

Option D - Volume expansion is indicated when there is known blood loss based on history and examination, and no response to epinephrine.

questions.text: You administer intravenous thiopentone for induction of anesthesia in a patient. As soon as you inject the drug, the patient complains of excruciating pain in his fingers, with burning sensation. Fingers turned pale initially and soon became cyanosed. Which of the following is not done in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of severe pain with burning sensation and cyanosis of fingers point to accidental intra-arterial administration of thiopentone. Saline administration via the same needle to dilute the drug should be the first step in managing this case. Therefore, removing the needle immediately is not a step in the management.

Intra-arterial injection of thiopentone can form crystals in the arterioles and capillaries, causing severe vasoconstriction, thrombosis, and even gangrene. The degree of gangrene corresponds to the concentration of the drug.

Treatment:

  • The needle should not be removed, as it can aggravate vasospasm.
  • Administer saline via the same needle, to dilute the drug.
  • Administer heparin to prevent thrombosis.
  • Administer papaverine and lidocaine.
  • Induce brachial plexus block or stellate ganglion block to relieve vasospasm.

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese female presents with a  2-year history of long periods of amenorrhea, followed by menorrhagia, along with excessive acne and increased facial, axillary, and pubic hair growth. Her prime concern is menstrual irregularity, for which she wants immediate resolution. On further questioning, she also mentions that she wants to have children after a few years. Which of the following will not be an appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a lady in the menstrual age group who is obese and hirsute, with acne and irregular cycles suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease/syndrome (PCOD/ PCOS). Ormeloxifene is not used as a treatment for polycystic ovarian disease.

Ormeloxifene (a selective estrogen receptor modulator), also known as centchroman, is a nonsteroidal contraceptive taken twice weekly as a 30 mg tablet for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It acts by preventing implantation. It can also be used in AUB due to its anti-estrogenic effects. It is contraindicated in PCOS.  

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states. CYP21 mutation and X-linked dominant inheritance patterns have been implicated in familial cases. 

It is characterized by:

Symptoms Signs 
Early adrenarche Obesity at the waistline, BMI>25
Early menarche  Goiter
Initially, normal menstruation followed by oligomenorrhea or periods of amenorrhea followed by menorrhagia  Hirsutism, acne
Infertility due to anovulation  Hypertension in obesity 
Pregnancy loss or high-risk pregnancies  Acanthosis nigricans 
Hyperandrogenism Acne, hirsutism, scalp baldness 

Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

USG findings of PCOS

  • Enlarged ovaries, volume >10 mm3
  • 12 or more follicles of 2–9 mm each placed peripherally (a string of pearls appearance)
  • Endometrial hyperplasia may be present

The image below shows a string-of-pearls appearance on USG indicative of PCOS.

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other options:

Option A: Ethinyl Estradiol + Drospirenone is a 4th generation combined oral contraceptive pill given for PCOD with androgenic features.

Option B: Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, thereby it decreases hyperinsulinemia. It also reduces the free and total testosterone and increases the sex hormone-binding globulin. It rectifies the root cause of the endocrine disturbance to restore ovulation and thereby improves the fertility rate. 

Option C: Spironolactone 100 mg to 200 mg daily has antiandrogenic effects and can be used in the treatment of androgenic features like severe hirsutism. Combination therapy with an oral contraceptive will be helpful in patients with PCOS.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A male patient presented with lower abdominal pain and an inability to urinate after an accident. He was conscious, and his vitals were stable.  X-ray showed a pelvic fracture that was managed conservatively. The retrograde cystogram showed a dense, flame-shaped collection of contrast in the pelvis. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of extraperitoneal bladder rupture associated with pelvic fracture. The next step in the management of this patient is Foley's catheterization.

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection as below:

  1. If the bladder rupture is above the peritoneal reflection (on the bladder dome), the urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal.
  2. If the bladder rupture is below the peritoneal reflection (eg: neck) and not on the dome, the urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage. The symptoms of extraperitoneal bladder injury are suprapubic pain with the inability to void.

CT cystography is the ideal investigation for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis. On retrograde cystogram, a dense, flame-shaped pattern of extravasation of the contrast material into the perivesical space and the fascia planes anterior to the peritoneum.

Uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injury is usually managed with urethral catheter drainage alone. Emergency operative management of bladder injury is done in:

  • Intraperitoneal injury from external trauma
  • Penetrating or iatrogenic non-urologic injury
  • Inadequate bladder drainage or clots in urine
  • Bladder neck injury
  • Rectal or vaginal injury
  • Open pelvic fracture
  • Pelvic fracture requiring open reduction and internal fixation
  • Selected stable patients undergoing laparotomy for other reasons 
  • Bone fragments projecting into the bladder

An algorithm for the management of bladder injury is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Suprapubic cystostomy is done in urethral injury.

Option B- Wait and watch is not a feasible option as there is extraperitoneal extravasation, which, if left untreated, can lead to peritonitis.

Option C- Exploratory laparotomy is done in intraperitoneal bladder rupture and other conditions as mentioned above.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presented with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and nausea at 8 weeks of gestation. Serum β-HCG level was found to be 5500 mIU/mL. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 5 cm gestational sac in the right fallopian tube, with fetal cardiac activity. There is no evidence of bleeding or rupture. What is the preferred mode of management for this patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up with β-HCG measurement

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The preferred mode of management in this scenario is surgical, suitably laparoscopic salpingostomy as she has not yet started a family.

Medical vs Surgical management

For an unruptured ectopic, the preferred mode of management is medical management with an injection of methotrexate. However, surgical management is preferred when:

  • Gestational sac size >4 cm
  • Serum β-HCG levels >5000 mIU/mL
  • Fetal heart rate (FHR) present
  • Patient hemodynamically unstable

Salpingectomy vs Salpingostomy

  • For an unruptured ectopic, either procedure can be done laparoscopically.
    • Salpingectomy - removal of the fallopian tube.
      • When the family is complete or
      • A desire for sterilization.
    • Salpingostomy - incising the tube to remove the tubal gestation but leaving the remainder of the tube intact.
      • When the family is incomplete or
      • A desire to retain fertility or
      • Contralateral tube is abnormal.
  • For a ruptured ectopic only salpingectomy can be done
    • Hemodynamically stable - laparoscopically done
    • Hemodynamically unstable - laparotomy is done

Other options:

Observation and β-hCG follow-up is part of the expectant management with hopes of spontaneous resolution. It is done only in a small subset of patients with unruptured ectopic gestation. Its indications are:

  • Initial serum β-hCG level <1000 mIU/mL and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestational sac size is <4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound.
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound.

Note: β-hCG follow-up is not just part of expectant management, it is done after all modes of treatment (medical, surgical, and expectant) to detect persistent trophoblastic disease.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. An intravenous urogram was obtained, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the intravenous urogram showing the drooping lily sign suggest the presence of a duplicated collecting system.

In a duplicated collecting system often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. Suppose the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed. In that case, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and looks like a drooping lily.

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage inferiorly: When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter might have an ectopic insertion in the bladder, urethra, or, vagina. 

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty.

Other options:

Option B: Ureterocele is caused due to the dilatation of the ureter as it passes through the bladder wall. It is visualized as a cobra head deformity on a pyelogram.

The image given below shows the cobra head sign.

Option C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is best visualized on ultrasounds and CT scans where the cyst is usually hypodense in contrast to the renal parenchyma. It may appear hyperdense if there is a hemorrhage present.

The image given below shows CT findings seen in childhood polycystic kidney disease.

Option D: Horseshoe kidney is a common congenital anomaly in which there is a fusion of the inferior poles of both kidneys. It is common in patients with Turner's syndrome.

The image shown below shows CT findings seen in the horseshoe kidney.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A neonate presents with facial dysmorphism as well as the characteristic findings shown in the image below. What is the chromosomal abnormality affecting this newborn?
questions.solution:
The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome. Edward's syndrome is caused due to trisomy 18.

Clinical features of Edward’s syndrome: (Remember the mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS)

  • Hypertonia
  • Microcephaly
  • Eighteen trisomy/ Elongated skull
  • Digit overlapping with a closed fist
  • Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes
  • Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/ Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis
  • Rocker bottom feet
  • Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) and kidney, death.
  • Small lower jaw (micrognathia), short sternum, small nipples

Other options: 

Option B: Trisomy 13 causes Patau syndrome. It is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities including cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects include polydactyly, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows the facial abnormalities seen in Patau syndrome:


Option C: Trisomy 21 causes Down syndrome. It is the most common chromosomal abnormality. Children with Down syndrome have severe mental retardation. They have characteristic facial features, including a flat profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and prominent epicanthic folds. There is a horizontal palmar crease and decreased muscle tone at birth that leads to a “floppy baby."


Option D: FGFR2 mutations are associated with craniosynostosis. FGFR2 mutation on chromosome 10q can cause Apert syndrome. It is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure of multiple cranial sutures, along with syndactyly/ mitten hand deformity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the Pediatrician with symptoms of common cold caused by rhinovirus. Which of the following receptors does this virus use to enter the cell?
questions.solution:
The receptor used by the rhinovirus to enter the cell is intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1).

Rhinoviruses are responsible for more than 50% of viral colds and have approximately 100 serotypes. Transmission is by contact with respiratory secretions.

Symptoms include profuse, watery nasal discharge frequently accompanied by symptoms of headache, malaise, sneezing, nasal congestion, sore throat, and cough. Illness generally lasts 10 days to 2 weeks. The infection is typically self-limiting.

Other options

Option B: CD21 is a complement receptor used by the Epstein-Barr virus.

Option C: Integrins are receptors interacting with the extracellular matrix that are used by the adenoviruses.

Option D: CD4, which is a part of the immunoglobulin superfamily, is utilized by HIV and human herpes 7 viruses to enter the cell.

questions.text: In a flowmeter sequence, which of the following cylinders is placed downstream?
questions.solution:
The oxygen flowmeter is located downstream of the other flowmeters. This is to avoid the generation of a hypoxic mixture in the event of any air leak.

In the first two images, A and B, the nitrous oxide flowmeter is located downstream and there is a leak in the airflow tube. Through this leak, most of the oxygen passes out and mainly nitrous oxide is provided at the outlet leading to the production of a hypoxic mixture.

But in the other two images, C and D, the oxygen flowmeter is located downstream. Through the leak in the airflow tube, some of the nitrous oxide passes out and the remaining passes out through the outlet with the oxygen. Thus the production of a hypoxic mixture is less likely if oxygen flowmeter is placed downstream.

questions.text:
Based on the flow-volume loop of a 58-year-old farmer, which is given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this 58-year-old farmer is restrictive airway disease. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity. Hence, the loop shifts towards the right.

In restrictive disorders (e.g. interstitial lung disease, kyphoscoliosis), the loop is narrowed because of diminished lung volumes. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates and mean expiratory flow is less than the mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to left.

Tracheal stenosis is a condition of fixed upper respiratory tract obstruction in which the loop shows a decreased flow rate during both inspiration and expiration.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with multibacillary leprosy was started on multidrug therapy that contains dapsone, rifampicin, and clofazimine. What type of drug is dapsone?
questions.solution:
Dapsone acts by inhibiting folic acid synthesis.

Dapsone [4,4‐diaminodiphenylsulphone (DDS)] is chemically related to sulfonamides. It is a structural analog of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and competitively inhibits dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway. It is bacteriostatic against Mycobacterium leprae.

Dapsone also has immunomodulatory, antiparasitic, and antifungal actions. It is used for the treatment of leprosy, and malaria. It is used for the prophylaxis of pneumocystosis and toxoplasmosis. Its anti-inflammatory effect is used to treat pemphigoid, relapsing chondritis, and dermatitis herpetiformis.

Adverse effects of dapsone include mild hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency, peripheral neuropathy, methemoglobinemia, and neuropsychiatric side effects.

DDS syndrome is a rare side effect of dapsone therapy in leprosy patients which starts after 5-6 weeks of starting dapsone and leads to exfoliative dermatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hepatitis and may be fatal. It is also called five-week dermatitis.

questions.text: An elderly woman who underwent a hip replacement surgery 1 week back now complains of hemoptysis and breathlessness. On examination, she complains of pain in her calf on pressing it, and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. The D-dimer levels are found to be elevated. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of deep vein thrombosis, breathlessness, and hemoptysis after major surgery with elevated levels of D-dimer suggest that the patient has a pulmonary embolism. The next step in the management of this patient is to perform a CT pulmonary angiography.

Approach to a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) should be suspected in a patient who complains of sudden breathlessness and hemoptysis after prolonged immobilization. Well's point score helps to estimate the clinical likelihood of PE. When patients' chances of PE are high, the patient should be assessed for D-dimer levels. Normal levels of D-dimer rule out the possibility of PE. If the D-dimer levels are elevated, then the chances of pulmonary embolism are very high and the patient should undergo imaging to confirm the diagnosis.

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It can provide exquisite detail, with ≤1 mm of resolution during a short breath-hold. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. In patients who do not have a pulmonary embolism, it can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Because of the invasive nature of pulmonary angiography (option B) and availability of chest CT scans, it is not commonly used in the diagnosis of PE. It is reserved for patients with technically unsatisfactory chest CTs and for those for whom an interventional procedure such as catheter-directed thrombolysis is planned.

Lung scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Small particulate aggregates of albumin labeled with a gamma-emitting radionuclide are injected intravenously and are trapped in the pulmonary capillary bed. The perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

MR pulmonary angiography is a reliable test to identify deep vein thrombosis. It may detect large proximal PE, but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram (option D). Therefore, it is not a reliable test to detect PE. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with pain in his shoulder. He has a history of anterior dislocation of the same shoulder 4 years back, following which he had recurrent similar episodes. The x-ray image of his shoulder is given below. What does the lesion marked in the image represent?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of recurrent anterior dislocation and an X-ray showing a fragment of bone from the anterior inferior glenoid rim is suggestive of a Bankart lesion.

Recurrent anterior dislocation causes stripping or avulsion of the glenoid labrum and the periosteum from the anterior inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck. In severe injuries, there may be the avulsion of a piece of bone from the anteroinferior glenoid rim, called a bony Bankart lesion.

Shoulder dislocations can be anterior, posterior, or inferior, but anterior dislocation is more common. It occurs due to falling on an outstretched hand when the shoulder joint is abducted and externally rotated. 

X-ray confirms shows the overlapping shadows of the humeral head and glenoid fossa. There may also be associated Hill-Sachs or Bankart lesions. Bankart lesion is a common complication and occurs secondary to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.

Other options:

Option A: Hill-Sachs lesion is a fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head as it dislocates.

The image below shows an X-ray of a Hill-Sachs lesion.

Option B: Luxatio eretca is another name for inferior dislocation of the shoulder. It is a rare type of shoulder dislocation, where the humeral head comes to lie in the subglenoid position.

Option D: Jefferson fracture is a burst fracture of the first cervical vertebra (atlas).

The image below shows a CT of Jefferson fracture. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 13-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty after sustaining an electric injury at home. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lichtenberg's figures or filigree burns are not seen in this type of electrical injury. They are a superficial, thin, tortuous, fern-like pattern of erythema on the skin and are pathognomonic of lightning burns.

The image given below shows Lichtenberg's figures.

Lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution:

Joule burns are specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. These are found at the point of the entry of the current. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter. 

The image given below shows a Joule burn.

Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and the conductor. They occur due to outer skin keratin melting over a small area which on cooling fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface. The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings. 

The crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions.

The image given below shows high voltage burns due to electrocution causing multiple spark lesions i.e. crocodile skin effect.

questions.text: A man is arrested by the police after multiple FIRs were registered against him for rubbing his genitals against women inappropriately in public transport. On questioning, the man says that he gets sexual gratification this way. Which of the following paraphilias describes this behavior?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of frotteurism. It refers to the sexual gratification obtained by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person. 

This behavior often occurs in busy, crowded places, such as on busy streets or on crowded buses or subways. It is predominantly described in men. A frotteur may fantasize that the woman he is rubbing up against is mutually aroused by the behavior.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities

Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments

Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporters in myocytes function under the influence of insulin?
questions.solution:
GLUT4 is the glucose transporter in the myocytes under the influence of insulin.

Glucose transport in our body mainly occurs through sodium-independent glucose transporters, which include GLUT transporters, and to a small extent through sodium-dependent glucose transporters, which include SGLT-1 and SGLT-2. Insulin induces the movement of intracellular GLUT4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake. In type 2 diabetes mellitus, membrane GLUT4 is reduced, leading to insulin resistance in muscle and fat cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida woman was tested positive for HIV. Which of the following is false regarding prevention of transmission of infection to the child?

choices.text: Immediately start mother on tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir
DNA-PCR for infant must be done immediately following birth
Syrup nevirapine to be given to the infant for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
DNA-PCR for infants is not done immediately following birth. It is done during the 1st post-delivery visit at 6 weeks.

The main goal of the prevention of parent-to-child transmission of HIV/AIDS (PPTCT) program is to offer HIV testing for all pregnant women.

According to this program, lifelong triple regimen ART is given to HIV+ pregnant and breastfeeding women regardless of their CD4 count and clinical stage of HIV. The preferred regimen is:

  • Tenofovir 300mg
  • Lamivudine 300mg
  • Dolutegravir 50mg

CD4 counts must be done for baseline value. However, ART must be started immediately without waiting for results. Cotrimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) must be started at 6 weeks.

HIV-exposed infants must be given exclusive breastfeeding or replacement feeding for 6 months. Daily syrup Nevirapine must be given for 6 weeks. Testing of HIV status of the infant is done as follows:

  • At 6 weeks, DNA/PCR
  • At 6 months, DNA/PCR + rapid test
  • At 18 months, 3 rapid test - confirmatory

All HIV-exposed infants must have the final confirmatory test at 18 months at ICTC. 6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding, another DNA/PCR + rapid test is done if any of the previous tests are positive.  

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A female patient presents with multiple itchy hypopigmented skin lesions. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing multiple hypopigmented macules and patches on the chest strongly suggest tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. The most likely causative agent are the Malassezia species.  

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor:

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause the degradation of lipid-producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Clinically, tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They may be mildly itchy and have fine scales. 

Lesions fluoresce under Wood’s lamp. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

Other options:

Option A: Piedraia hortae is a non-pathogenic opportunist that infects human hair causing black piedra. It is characterized by dark, hardened nodules firmly attached to the hair.

Option B: Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea werneckii/ Phaeoannellomyces werneckii/ Cladosporium werneckii cause tinea nigra–gray to black non-inflammatory, non-scaling, well-demarcated macular lesions usually on the palm.

Option D: Microsporum causes dermatophytosis/ tinea/ ringworm.

questions.text: Acidification of urine is useful in the toxicity management of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Acidification of the urine is useful in the management of amphetamine toxicity.

The renal tubules are highly permeable to the nonionized forms of weak acids and bases undergo net passive reabsorption. However, they are less permeable to the ionized forms of weak acids and bases. Therefore, passive reabsorption of these substances depends on the pH of the urine.

 

Acidic urine

Alkaline urine

Weak acid

Non-ionized and reabsorbed

Ionized and excreted

Weak base

Ionized and excreted

Non-ionized and reabsorbed

Amphetamine is a weakly basic drug. When the urine is acidic, weakly basic drugs are highly ionized and excreted more rapidly.

Urinary alkalinization speeds up the clearance of barbiturates, sulphonamides, salicylates, chlorpropamide, methotrexate, and chlorophenoxy herbicides.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her mother revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and RR was 36 breaths/ minute. Which of the following is not a causative agent of her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS) following septic abortion. Escherichia coli can be detected in septic abortion, but it is not a causative agent for TSS.

Organisms causing toxic shock syndrome in septic abortion:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Clostridium perfringens
  • Clostridium sordellii

Clinical features of septic abortion:

  • Fever with chills and rigors
  • Abdominal or chest pain
  • Diarrhoea and vomiting
  • Renal angle tenderness
  • Offensive purulent vaginal discharge.

Clinical grading of septic abortion:

  • Grade I - infection localized in the uterus
  • Grade II - infection spreads to parametrium, tubes, ovaries, or pelvic peritoneum
  • Grade III - generalized peritonitis, endotoxic shock, jaundice, or acute renal failure

Empirical antibiotic therapy in septic abortion is started for the broadest microbial coverage. Piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem and clindamycin are given intravenously. Antibiotics can be changed once culture sensitivity reports are available.

questions.text: A prisoner who was brought to the hospital with deafness after a brawl with another inmate is suspected of malingering. Which of the following tests can be used to assess the authenticity of his complaints?
questions.solution:
Impedance audiometry can be used to test malingering. It is an objective test and consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

A person who feigns total deafness and does not give any response on pure tone audiometry but shows a positive acoustic reflex is a malingerer.

questions.text:
A patient presented with features shown in the image. His lipid profile showed almost nil HDL levels. Which of the following is deficient in this condition?

HDL - High density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with orange tonsils and nil HDL suggests a diagnosis of Tangier's disease. It is caused by a defect in ABCA1 receptors.

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells to HDL. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus defective ABCA1 will lead to almost nil HDL in the blood. 

Other options:

Option B: Defective LDL receptor points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia). This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease, which is a lysosomal storage disease. Pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

questions.text: A patient presented with lateral gaze palsy in the left eye, with ataxia of the left arm and leg.  He also has paralysis of the right arm, legs, and face, along with loss of touch sensation and proprioception over the right side of the body. Where is the lesion most likely to be located?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of medial pontine syndrome, which occurs due to a lesion located at the medial pons.

The medial pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the paramedian branch of the basilar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestation
    • CN VI: Diplopia (lateral rectus muscle paralysis - the affected eye looks downwards and inwards)
    • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait
  • Contralateral manifestation
    • Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract: Paralysis of face, arm, and leg
    • Medial lemniscus: loss of touch and proprioception from the body.

The lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying the epidemiology of tuberculosis. Which of the following is a component of the 'Triangle of epidemiology' of TB that differentiates it from the 'Epidemiological triad' of TB?
questions.solution:
Duration of illness is not a part of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis, but its a part of traingle of epidemiology.

The epidemiological triad includes host, agent and environment. 

Hence, a malnourished child (host), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (agent) and overcrowding (environment) form the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis.

 

Note: The triangle of epidemiology includes host, agent, environment and time. Hence, duration of illness (time) is a part of the triangle of epidemiology.

questions.text: An 11-month-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of 12-14 episodes of loose, watery, non-blood-stained stools for the last two days. On examination, the temperature is 98.8 F, pulse rate is 130/minute, and respiratory rate is 45/minute. The child appears lethargic with sunken eyes and skin turgor is reduced with recoil in 3 secs. Which of the following is incorrect about the management protocol in this patient as per the WHO IMNCI plans?

choices.text: The fluid replacement should be done over 6 hours
Both Ringer's lactate and normal saline can be used for resuscitation
The total fluid requirement in this patient is 75 mL/kg
ORS can be given as a bridge to definitive management

questions.solution:
This child with a history of watery diarrhea has severe dehydration based on examination findings (sunken eyes, tachycardia, lethargy). This child should be started on IV fluids (either Ringer's Lactate or Normal saline) at the rate of 100 mL/kg over 6 hours as she is less than 12 months of age.
