Image 1 shows the lambda sign (also known as the twin peak sign) in ultrasonography, seen in dichorionic diamniotic gestation. Its presence is highly suggestive of dichorionicity.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

The image given below shows the lambda/twin peak.


Image 2 shows the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II malformation.


Image 3 shows the bagel sign which is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

The image given below shows the bagel sign.


Image 4 shows the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation. It is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

The image given below shows a T sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with a cognitive deficit, involuntary hand and finger movements, and muscle incoordination. He was diagnosed with Huntington's chorea. Which brain structure marked in the given image shrinks rapidly in his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Huntington's disease. The caudate nucleus, which is marked "A," shrinks dramatically in Huntington's disease and, if affected, is also a major cause of chorea movements.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in chorea and dementia and which demonstrates anticipation. The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. Commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decade of life; motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia.

Markings:

A - Caudate nucleus

B - Thalamus

C - Globus pallidus

D - Putamen

The above image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: A clinical trial is done to compare the safety profile of a certain direct thrombin inhibitor (drug X) with that of heparin in patients undergoing coronary angioplasty. Identify drug X.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the direct thrombin inhibitor is bivalirudin. 

Bivalirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) frequently used for anticoagulation in invasive cardiology, particularly percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Unlike other DTIs, it undergoes predominant non-organ elimination (proteolysis) and has the shortest half-life (approximately 25 min).

It can be used in patients with, or at risk for, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Other options:

Options A and D: Enoxaparin and dalteparin are low-molecular-weight-heparin (LMWH) preparations. 

Option C: Fondaparinux is a synthetic analog of the pentasaccharide unit of heparin. 

Heparins and their analogs produce anticoagulant effects indirectly by activating antithrombin-III.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ER with weakness in both legs since yesterday. The weakness has progressed to his arms now and he is having difficulty in breathing. He had an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis in all four limbs and arreflexia. CSF examination shows elevated protein levels but normal cell count. What is the further management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of ascending, flaccid type of paralysis following an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago, and CSF examination showing increased protein with normal cell count, point to a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). 

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The possible antecedent events include respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. The implicated organisms include Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, and Mycoplasma pneumonia.

The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Autonomic involvement usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension. Fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of the weakness. Similarly, bladder dysfunction occurs only in severe GBS and is transient. Prominent bladder dysfunction occurring early in the disease course goes against the diagnosis of GBS. 

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, there's a plateauing of the symptoms and any further deterioration is unlikely.

The treatment for GBS should be initiated as early as possible. High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis can be used for the treatment. A sequential combination of the two has not been found to be more effective than either of them alone. Corticosteroids (option A) are not effective in the treatment of GBS.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a

  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: There are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells. How is this phenomenon best explained?
questions.solution:
The statement 'there are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells' is explained by the Donnan effect.

The Donnan effect states that, in the presence of a non-diffusible ion such as negatively charged protein, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

For example, let's consider that there are two compartments X and Y, containing potassium and chloride ions, which are diffusible, and negatively charged proteins in compartment X.

As the protein is non-diffusible, the potassium and chloride ions diffuse such that their concentration ratios are equal.

The Donnan effect on the distribution of ions has three effects:

  • Due to the presence of non-diffusible negatively charged proteins in the cells, there are more osmotically active particles in cells than in interstitial or inter-cellular fluid. The presence of more osmotically active particles drags water into the cells, which may eventually cause the cells to swell and rupture. This is prevented by the presence of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which pumps the ions back out of the cells.
  • At equilibrium, the distribution of the diffusible ions is asymmetric. This causes an electrical difference exists across the membrane.
  • There are more proteins in the plasma than in the interstitial fluid. The resultant Donnan effect is responsible for the movement of the ions across the capillary wall.

questions.text: A patient with measles comes to the fever OPD. This disease is transmitted via the air-borne mode of transmission. Identify the true statement regarding the same.

choices.text: It is a droplet-mediated indirect mode of transmission.
It is a droplet-mediated direct mode of transmission.
It is a droplet nuclei–mediated indirect mode of transmission.
It is a droplet nuclei–mediated direct mode of transmission.

questions.solution:
The airborne mode of transmission is a droplet nuclei–mediated indirect mode of transmission.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (Eg: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with infertility, and a cervical mucus study was performed on the 24th day of her menstrual cycle (she has a regular 28 days cycle). Which of the following is not true regarding the interpretation of the findings shown in this test?

choices.text: This finding is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus.
This phenomenon occurs under the influence of estrogen.
This test indicates that ovulation has occurred in this patient.
Corpus luteum is absent during this time of her cycle.

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus with ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. The persistence of ferning beyond day 22 indicates anovulation. In this patient, ferning is present on the 24th day, which indicates that her cycles are anovulatory.

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (estrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the estrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, and viscosity as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge associated with itching and burning. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing curdy white vaginal discharge is suggestive of monilial vaginitis/vaginal candidiasis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg can be used in the treatment of this condition.

Local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole, miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole or ter­conazole vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3–6 days is also very effective. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include pregnancy, medications such as oral contraceptive pills, steroids, HIV, and diabetes mellitus. Clinical features include itching, curdy-white discharge, burning, and dysuria with vaginal pH <4.5. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. Culture can be done on Sabouraud's agar and Nickerson's medium.

Treatment includes control and elimination of risk factors including maintaining personal hygiene, adequate control of diabetes, and stopping contributing medications, in addition to pharmacotherapy as mentioned above. Routine treatment of the partner is not recommended unless the partner is symptomatic.

Other options:

Option A- Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

Option B- Azithromycin 1 g single dose is used in the treatment of chlamydial infections and chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D- Metronidazole 2 g single dose is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying the various growth phases of a bacterium. The findings are plotted in the image below. Viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in which of the growth phases shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is denoted by 3 in the above image.

The image given below shows a graph plotting the log of the number of bacteria against time in a population of cells termed batch culture denoting the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation of the cells to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence, by the end of the lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained.

Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time. One of two things limits this exponential growth:

  • Exhaustion of nutrients in the medium required for growth
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites that inhibits growth

Stationary phase: When exponential growth of cells is limited, the cells enter a stationary phase where cell growth ceases completely. Cell turnover is seen where the rate at which cells die is equally balanced with the rate of formation of new cells through growth and division. In this phase, a bacterial culture phenomenon is noted where bacterial cells become viable but non-culturable (VBNC). This is thought to be triggered by starvation where the bacterial cells enter into a dormant state resulting in no morphological changes. When appropriate conditions are met, VNBC microbes resume growth.

Phase of decline: Cell viability begins to decrease at a defined rate and as a result cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death. The death rate increases until it reaches a steady level.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness. Her heart rate is 135 beats/ minute. Her ECG strip is shown below. Which of the following treatment modalities is recommended for definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The recommended treatment modality is radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway. 

Wolf Parkinson White (WPW) is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave as seen in the picture.

Patients with WPW may be asymptomatic or have multiple recurrent arrhythmias with chest pain, dizziness, or sudden cardiac arrest. The initial treatment of WPW involves vagal manoeuvres to abort the tachycardia. Pharmacologic therapy with adenosine, verapamil, or beta-blockers can be administered. However, as recurrent arrhythmias may lead to AF, radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway is advised for definitive treatment.

Other options: 

Option A: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is not used to treat WPW. Ablation has a better prognosis. 

Options B and D: Percutaneous coronary intervention and coronary artery bypass grafting are done in patients who have had a myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios would you use the instrument shown in the given image?

choices.text: Fetus at 33 weeks gestation with respiratory distress
Baby weighing 4 kg in cephalic presentation
Term fetus with face as the presenting part
Term baby with maternal mitral valve prolapse

questions.solution:
The given image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery system. Among the given options, a term fetus with maternal mitral valve prolapse would be delivered using this system in order to minimize maternal exhaustion and to cut short the second stage of labor.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. 

The instrument consists of 

  • Suction cup,
  • Vacuum generator, and
  • Traction tubing device.

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about 6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.

Once the cup is placed over the flexion point, the ventouse extraction begins by slowly initiating a vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute until the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm2 and then traction is applied.

The traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous with the uterine contractions. In between the uterine contractions, the traction is released. The traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if there is no descent of the presenting part with each pull and delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed beyond 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve, and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with a soft tissue tumor of the lower leg. The tumor closely approximates the knee joint but does not appear to arise within or communicate with the synovium. Microscopy reveals a spindled-cell proliferation with admixed epithelial components, and molecular testing shows an X;18 translocation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient has synovial sarcoma, which is a misnomer as the soft tissue malignancy does not appear to be related to the synovium.
  • It is commonly biphasic with both spindled and epithelial components demonstrable on both light microscopy and immunohistochemistry.
  • Monophasic sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with little cytoplasm but dense chromatin in tightly packed fascicles.
  • Immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing these tumours as the epithelial antigens (keratins) differentiate synovial sarcomas from other sarcomas.
  • The characteristic translocation involves X;18. While the demonstration of t(X;18) is required to confirm a diagnosis of synovial sarcoma, it is not entirely specific for this entity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Splenic vein thrombosis is a prehepatic cause of portal hypertension.

Splenic vein thrombosis can be caused by pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronic pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend beyond the pancreas and invade the splenic vein. This thrombosis causes increased pressure in the splenic vein, leading to the formation of collaterals and, ultimately, gastric variceal haemorrhage (not esophageal varices).

Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are the features that differentiate portal hypertension due to splenic vein thrombosis from other forms of portal hypertension. In this type, the portal vein pressures remain normal since there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature.

Diagnosis is made by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with Doppler), and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. 

Treatment includes splenectomy and management of the primary pancreatic pathology. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with dysmorphic facies was brought to the clinic with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections of the skin, mouth, and respiratory tract. Interestingly, the baby has a Bombay blood group. Which of the following is likely to be associated with the underlying condition in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD)- type 2, which results from defective fucose incorporation. Craniofacial dysmorphism and the Bombay blood group are features unique to LAD-2.

LAD-2 is also known as the congenital disorder of glycosylation II-C. This abnormality prevents the incorporation of fucose into various cell surface glycoproteins, including the carbohydrate structure Sialyl Lewis X, which is critical for the rolling and adhesion of neutrophils to vascular endothelium.

Other options:

Option A- Defective β2 integrin occurs in LAD-1 in which steady adhesion of leukocyte to endothelial surfaces is defective. Some of the characteristics seen in LAD-1 are delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent pyogenic infections with onset in the first week of life, infections caused by Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, absent pus formation, and periodontitis. 

Option C- Defective kindlin-3 gene, which affects integrin activation cascade, is seen in LAD-3. LAD-3 is characterized by a Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, and skin and soft tissue infections similar to those seen in LAD-1.

Option D- Defective lysosomal traffic regulator (LYST) gene in chromosome 1 is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Patients have light skin and silvery hair. They frequently complain about recurrent infections, photosensitivity, photophobia, infections, and neuropathy. 

Note:

Both LAD and CHS are autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.text: Using the procedure depicted in the given image, all of the following can be measured, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of spirometry and Functional residual capacity (FRC) cannot be recorded using it. 

The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after the expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume. As residual volume cannot be measured by spirometry, lung capacities that include the residual volume also cannot be measured by spirometry (i.e., FRC and TLC).

Spirometry cannot measure the following lung volumes and capacities:
  • Residual volume (RV)
  • Closing volume (CV)
  • Functional residual capacity (ERV +  RV)
  • Total lung capacity (TLC)

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. Therefore, it gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with progressive conductive hearing loss was found to have otosclerotic foci on the entire footplate along with complete involvement of the oval window. What type of otosclerosis is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
The otosclerotic foci found on the entire footplate of stapes along with complete involvement of the oval window is an obliterative type of stapedial otosclerosis.

The stapedial type of otosclerosis presents predominantly with a bilateral conductive type of deafness and can be of various types:

  • Anterior focus: Involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
  • Posterior focus: Only fissula post fenestrum
  • Circumferential: Around the margin of the stapes footplate
  • Biscuit type: Entire footplate except for the annular ligament
  • Obliterative: Entire footplate when it completely obliterates the oval window niche.

Otosclerosis is a bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. This condition worsens during stress and conditions with hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis Any site but asymptomatic

 

Clinical features

  • An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.
  • In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The image below shows the Schwartze sign.

  • Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).
  • Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch. 

The image below shows Carhart's notch in pure tone audiometry. 

  • Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicating that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. 

The image below shows As type of curve in tympanometry which is seen in otosclerosis.

  • As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Image below shows stapedotomy procedure.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
The actions carried out by the superior oblique muscle are intorsion, depression, and abduction.

There are six extraocular muscles for each eye. Four rectus muscles namely - superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti. The oblique muscles are two - superior oblique and inferior oblique. These muscles are responsible for the movements of the eye which can be either unilateral or binocular movements.

The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator. The oblique direction of the tendon is responsible for its rotatory effect (intorsion), in addition to depression and abduction.

 

Unilateral movements (ductions) are :

1.Adduction: It is the movement towards the nasal side around the vertical axis.

2.Abduction: It is the movement towards the temporal side around the vertical axis.

3.Supraduction (elevation): It is upward movement around the horizontal axis.

4.Infraduction (depression): It is downward movement around the horizontal axis.

5.Intorsion (medial rotation): Rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis where the superior pole of cornea moves medially.

6.Extorsion (lateral rotation): Rotatory movement along the anteroposterior axis where the superior pole of cornea moves laterally.

Binocular movements can be of two types - versions and vergences.

The oculomotor nerve supplies all the extraocular muscles except the superior oblique and lateral rectus. The superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve and lateral rectus muscle by the abducent nerve.

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: A 65-year-old multiparous woman presents to you with complaints of involuntary leakage of urine on coughing, sneezing, and lifting of heavy objects. Which of the following is least likely to be the treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of urinary incontinence on coughing, sneezing, and lifting heavy objects in a multiparous female in a post-menopausal age group is suggestive of genuine stress incontinence (GSI). Bladder training is a treatment option for detrusor instability (not for GSI).

GSI is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction.
 
Grading of GSI:
  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management of GSI:

  1. Kegel pelvic floor exercises
  2. Drugs - Alpha-adrenergic drugs, venlafaxine, imipramine, and estrogen cream.
  3. Ring pessaries/vaginal cones
  4. Electric stimulation
  5. Artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) system

Surgical management of GSI:

  • Vaginal Operations: 
    • Kelly’s repair: Anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck
    • Pacey’s repair: Apposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscles in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it
  • Abdominal Operations:
    • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation: Retropubic colposuspension, where bladder neck and the vaginal vault are sutured to the periosteum of the back of the pubic symphysis
    • Burch's colposuspension: Vaginal suspension achieved using the iliopectineal ligament
    • Laparoscopic colposuspension
  • Combined abdominal and vaginal operations: Pereyra operation
  • Tension-free vaginal tapes
  • Periurethral collagen injection

Detrusor instability: Incontinence happens when the detrusor muscle contracts on provocation or spontaneously during the filling phase when inhibition of micturition is attempted. It is mostly caused by parasympathetic overactivity, seen most commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presented with left-sided undescended testis and hypospadias. Ultrasonography showed the presence of an ovary on the left side and fully descended testes on the right side. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of true hermaphroditism.

It is a rare disorder characterized by the presence of both ovaries and testes in the same individual. It is also known as ovo-testicular disorder of sexual differentiation. 

Morphologically, the presence of both gonads can be asymmetrical having both ovarian and testicular differentiation on either side separately or combined as ovotestis within the same gonad or symmetrical with normal testes and ovary on both sides.

These gonads can vary in location from the abdomen to the inguinoscrotal region. The amount of anti-Mullerian hormone and testosterone determines the degree of masculinization or feminization of the internal ductal system.

Clinical presentation includes ambiguous external genitalia, chordee, hypospadias, cryptorchidism, amenorrhea, lower abdominal pain, and inguinal hernias. The phallus size usually helps to determine the choice of rearing hermaphrodite as male or female sex. Adequately sized phallus can be retained with meticulous surgical excision of the female genital organs.

Other options:

Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia due to the absence of 5 alpha-reductase enzyme. 5 alpha-reductase is responsible for the development of the male phenotype. There is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

Option B: Female pseudohermaphrodites are genetic females (XX genotype) with male/ambiguous external genitalia due to the deficiency of 21 alpha-hydroxylase enzymes resulting in an excess of androgens. This causes clitoromegaly resembling the penis, and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum. 

Option D: Concealed sex refers to the deliberate concealment of sex usually done by criminals by changing dress or by other methods to avoid detection. This can be detected by physical examination.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck, as shown in the image. The slip sign is negative, and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly transilluminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue.
  • Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline.
  • Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Option C: Lipoma is less commonly seen in children. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text:
A woman on oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) should be warned of potential failure of contraception while prescribing which of the following drugs?

1. Valproate
2. Rifampicin
3. Phenytoin
4. Phenobarbitone
questions.solution:
Contraceptive failure in patients on the oral contraceptive pill is likely to occur with rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone.

Rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers and can cause increased metabolism of OCPs leading to contraceptive failure.

Valproate does not cause contraceptive failure. It is an enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the degradation of OCPs and increases their duration of action.

questions.text: Which agency provides assistance to India in the procurement of supplies like x-ray units, microscopes, and drugs for tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA) provides assistance to India in the procurement of supplies like x-ray units, microscopes, and drugs for tuberculosis under the National Tuberculosis Control Program. 

Other options:

Option A: CARE- Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere aims at providing food for children in the age group of 6-11 years. It is also helping in projects like integrated nutrition and health project, better health and nutrition projects, anemia control projects, etc.

Option B: UNDP- The United Nations Development Program provides funds for technical assistance. Its main objective is to help poorer nations in developing their human and natural resources. 

Option D: DANIDA- The Danish International Development Agency provides assistance for the development of services under the National Blindness Control Program.

questions.text: As part of a research program, a community is being tested by three screening tests for COVID-19. The patient is considered diseased if he/she tests positive in any one of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this pattern of screening?
questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a number of screening tests being conducted in parallel, where the net specificity is low. 

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • This increases the number of false negatives.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • Tests are said to be in parallel when a positive result on any one or more tests is considered sufficient to classify a patient into the diseased group.
  • A subject is considered nondiseased only when they test negative by all the tests.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.
  Tests in Series Tests in parallel

Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

questions.text:
A patient presented with lethargy and muscle cramps. He was diagnosed with SIADH. Which of the following drugs can be administered orally for the management of his condition?

SIADH - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
questions.solution:
Tolvaptan is a selective oral V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for and is effective in clinically significant hyponatremia associated with SIADH.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

Other options:

Options A and D: Terlipressin and desmopressin are not used in the treatment of SIADH. SIADH is a condition of inappropriate ADH secretion. Since excess vasopressin is the cause of SIADH, giving vasopressin analogs as desmopressin would only worsen the condition. 

Option C: Conivaptan is a nonselective V1a receptor/V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for the treatment of hospitalized patients with euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. It is available only for intravenous infusion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with rapidly growing painful swelling in the angle of the jaw on the right side, with ipsilateral facial palsy. FNAC confirmed mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. She underwent a total radical parotidectomy. Which of the following is the best for nerve grafting in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best nerve for grafting in total radical parotidectomy is the sural nerve.

In total radical parotidectomy, both the superficial and deep lobes of the parotid and the facial nerve are removed. A cable graft is used to bridge the gap. The commonly used are the interpositional greater auricular nerve and sural nerve (best) grafts.

Surgery:

If only the superficial lobe is involved:

  • superficial parotidectomy- only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions.

If both lobes are involved:

  • Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved.
  • Total radical parotidectomy- both lobes and facial nerve removed.

questions.text: An intern who aspires to be a surgeon did not qualify in the entrance exam. He now claims that the syllabus changed completely this year as compared to the previous year. What is the defense mechanism being used here?
questions.solution:
Justifying his inability to qualify for the exam with an excuse that the syllabus changed completely is an example of rationalization.

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

Projection is an immature defense mechanism and it involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

With regards to prostate carcinoma, which of the following Gleason's grade group is incorrectly matched with Gleason's score?
Options Gleason's grade group Gleason's score
A Group 1 6
B Group 2 7
C Group 3 8
D Group 5 10
questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched option is option C.

A prostate cancer patient with Gleason's grade groups 2 and 3 both have a score of 7.

Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:

1) Gleason Pattern:

    • Pattern 3- Well formed glands
    • Pattern 4- Poorly formed/ Fused/ Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands

The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man sustained a closed, diaphyseal tibial fracture of the left leg in a road traffic accident. As he had no distal neurovascular deficits or any open wound, he was managed conservatively with a cast for 6 weeks. After this period, he noticed a significant reduction in the girth of his left calf compared to the right. What is the type of atrophy likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Disuse atrophy due to decreased workload is seen in this scenario. Disuse atrophy occurs in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture.

Physiologic atrophy:

  • Loss of hormonal stimulation: Atrophy of the uterus after parturition; atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause.
  • During embryonic development: Certain structures, like the notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathologic atrophy:

  • Disuse Atrophy (decreased workload): e.g., atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
  • Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): e.g., skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
  • Ischemic atrophy: e.g., senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
  • Inadequate nutrition: e.g., severe muscle wasting in marasmus
  • Pressure atrophy: e.g., atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor 

Mechanisms of atrophy:

  • Decreased protein synthesis because of decreased metabolic activity
  • Increased destruction of proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

questions.text: Within 24 hours of induction of spinal anesthesia, a patient develops bilateral pain in the buttocks, radiating to the legs. This pain lasts less than a week. Which of the following drugs has the highest likelihood of causing such symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes transient neurological symptoms. Transient neurological symptoms (TNS) have the highest incidence with lidocaine.

TNS was previously known as transient radicular irritation. It is mostly attributed to the use of intrathecal lidocaine and mepivacaine. It is most common in patients who were placed in a lithotomy position during surgery.

Symptoms occur within 48 hours of the resolution of the spinal anesthetic. It presents as unilateral or bilateral pain in the buttocks that radiates to the legs. 

It is not related to the concentration of lidocaine, the addition of dextrose or epinephrine or solution osmolarity. Its incidence is decreased by the use of a double-orifice needle since single-orifice needles can increase the risk of injecting the anesthetic caudally in the thecal sac.

This condition is usually self-limiting. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can be given. Some patients may require opioids.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of pigmentation on her face, as shown in the image. She says that this has been present for one year, and there was no pigmentation prior to that. On examination, it appears flat, with an irregular border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is lentigo maligna melanoma.

Lentigo maligna melanoma (Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle) is a variant of malignant melanoma that occurs most commonly in sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, and forearms. It is more commonly seen in elderly females than males. It starts as a flat, dark, variably pigmented lesion with irregular borders as shown in the image. It develops slowly over months and years. It has less malignant potential as they take a longer time to attain the vertical growth phase.

Other options:

Option A:

Acral lentiginous melanoma is the most common melanoma in darker-skinned patients. It is usually seen in people above 60 years of age. It occurs in subungual areas beneath the fingernails, toenails, palms of hands, and soles of feet. It presents as a flat, irregular macule often described as a 'dirty-like stain' as shown below. 

Option C:

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant of malignant melanoma. It is more commonly seen on the trunk and proximal extremities. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a chronic period of change in color and border. It presents as an atypical nevus that progressively becomes irregular in shape and appears in shades of brown, black, grey, red as well as depigmented areas. It undergoes rapid growth a few months before presentation. They later develop a vertical growth phase resulting in nodule formation that may bleed or ulcerate. 

Below is the image showing the dermoscopy of superficial spreading melanoma. 

Option D:

Nodular melanoma is the most aggressive variant of malignant melanoma. They arise de novo in the skin and are more common in men than women. They can occur anywhere on the body but are usually found on the trunk, head, or neck. They present as symmetrical, elevated, dome-shaped polypoid or pedunculated lesions as shown below. They lack a horizontal growth phase and have a poor prognosis.

Below is the image showing nodular melanoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle. On examination, the test shown below is positive. She has a past history of deep vein thrombosis. What is the minimum Wells score for pulmonary embolism in this patient based on the given information?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The most common clinical presentation of DVT is pain and tenderness in the calf. The given image shows the method of eliciting Moses sign, which is calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The minimum Well's score in this patient from the information given is 4.5.

Calculation of minimum Modified Wells score in this case:

Note: To calculate the final score, All the other components are needed. The question asks about the minimum score based on the information given only. 

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely >4
  • PE unlikely <or =4

DVT is mostly unilateral, with an unreliable clinical examination. Pulmonary embolism is the most common complication of DVT and may present directly as pulmonary thromboembolism.

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes:

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites:

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT:

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homans and Moses sign
  • Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Moses sign - Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below.

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

questions.text: A 15-year-old presented with a cherry red, polypoidal mass detected on anterior rhinoscopy. Biopsy of the mass suggested that it originated from the olfactory neural epithelium. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma. It arises from the olfactory epithelium of the upper third of the nose.

Related Pearl: Esthesioneuroblastoma

Esthesioneuroblastoma is known as olfactory neuroblastoma or olfactory placode tumor.

It arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper 1/3 rd of the nose. It has a bimodal age distribution (10-20 and 50-60 years)

Clinical features:

  • Unilateral nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis 
  • Friable cherry-red, vascular polypoidal mass in the upper third of the nasal cavity

Investigation of choice is biopsy after appropriate imaging showing the extent of the tumor.

The tumor may be low grade with pseudorosettes or high grade with nuclear pleomorphism. Lymph node metastasis can occur in 10-15% cases.

Treatment is surgery which can be combined with preoperative chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

questions.text: A male patient presented with a chronic, progressively enlarging, indurated ulcer on his left hand for the past 1 month. He says that he takes bath daily in a pond. A diagnosis of Buruli ulcer is suspected. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is endemic to tropical wetlands.
It is caused by Mycobacterium marinum.
Rifampicin and streptomycin are used for treatment.

questions.solution:
Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma/ fish tank granuloma.

Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans - a fastidious, slow-growing bacterium. It is the third most common mycobacterial infection in humans, following tuberculosis and leprosy.

It is closely associated with tropical wetlands, and transmission occurs via mosquitoes and aquatic biting arthropods.

It is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue. It is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. 

The image given below shows a Buruli ulcer.

It can also manifest as a subcutaneous nodule, plaque, or an aggressive edematous infection of the soft tissue. Ulcers are usually seen on the legs or arms. They heal with disfiguring scars. Regional lymph nodes are not involved; no systemic invasion.
 
The smear from the edge of the ulcer shows large clumps of acid-fast bacilli.
 
Treatment:
  • Duration: 8 weeks
  • Antibiotics:
    • Rifampicin plus streptomycin
    • Rifampicin plus clarithromycin
    • Rifampicin plus moxifloxacin
  • Surgical debridement, skin grafting, wound care.

questions.text: A 32-year-old diabetic man was undergoing a routine check-up. ECG revealed ST changes as given below. Repeated cardiac biomarkers were found to be within the normal range. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows coved ST-segment elevation of V1-V3, followed by a negative T wave (Brugada sign), which points to a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. A coved ST segment has a downward concavity.

Brugada syndrome is an inherited sodium channelopathy (SCN5A mutation) most commonly seen in Southeast Asian males. The age of presentation is usually 40 years. This syndrome is characterised by an increased risk of sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

To establish a diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (Option B) and NSTEMI (Option D), a positive and significant rise in cardiac biomarkers (troponins) is necessary along with one of the following features:

  • Symptoms of ischemia
  • New ST-T elevation or LBBB (not for NSTEMI)
  • Pathologic Q waves (STEMI, old infarcts)
  • Imaging evidence of loss of myocardium viability
  • Intracoronary thrombus identified on angioplasty or autopsy

Since we do not have a typical rise and fall pattern of cardiac biomarkers, in this case, a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI is less likely.

Causes of ST-T changes apart from acute MI:

  • Acute pericarditis (Option C) - Diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and PR depression)
  • Brugada patterns (right bundle branch block-like pattern with ST elevations in right precordial leads) seen secondary to electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia
  • Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves)

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby presents with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when weaning was started with fruit juice. Which of the following can give a positive reaction in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the above clinical features after the initiation of fruit juice (rich in fructose) suggests a disorder of fructose metabolism. Seliwanoff's reagent gives a positive reaction in this condition.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause glycogen accumulation in the liver and associated hypoglycemia.

Symptoms occur when sucrose (fructose+glucose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Fructose is also excreted in the urine. This gives a positive reducing sugar test (Benedict's test), a positive test for furfural derivatives, and specifically a positive Seliwanoff's test (for fructose). Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will immediately relieve the symptoms

Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar. The blue color indicates the absence of sugar in the urine. The green precipitate means 0.5%, yellow (1%), orange (1.5%) and red indicates 2% or more sugar (1% means 1 g per 100 ml). 

Furfural test: Monosaccharides when treated with concentrated sulphuric acid undergo dehydration with the removal of 3 molecules of water. Hexoses give hydroxymethylfurfural and pentoses give furfural. The furfural derivative can condense with phenolic compounds to give colored products. This forms the basis of the Molisch test. It is a general test for carbohydrates.
