questions.text: During oogenesis,  when will the arrest of the secondary oocyte occur?
questions.solution:
The secondary oocyte gets arrested during meiosis-2 in the metaphase of the cell cycle.

Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. Primordial germ cells divide by mitosis to form oogonia.

The majority of the oogonia divide by mitosis, however, some enter meiosis I and get arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase and are now called primary oocytes. These primary oocytes remain arrested in this manner until puberty. Primary oocytes haven't completed meiosis, hence they're diploid. The primary oocyte along with surrounding epithelial cells forms the primordial follicle.

Meiosis I is completed after LH surge during puberty to form the secondary oocyte. The cell then enters meiosis II but arrests in metaphase approximately 3 hours before ovulation.

If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte fails to complete the second meiotic division and degenerates about 24 hours after ovulation. If fertilization occurs, penetration by the sperm signals the secondary oocyte to complete meiosis II. This results in one mature oocyte (ovum) and another smaller cell called the second polar body that is shed off.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient had 6 attacks of migraine in the last month and was treated for the same. She is not able to tolerate the pain during attacks and came to the hospital asking for medication that can prevent these attacks in the future. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topiramate can be used in this patient to prevent migraine attacks.

In patients with ≥4 attacks of migraine in a month, prophylactic medications can be used. The various FDA-approved drugs include propranolol, timolol, rimegepant, sodium valproate, topiramate, eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, and galcanezumab.

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Other modalities of preventive treatment:

  • Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in the prevention of chronic migraine
  • Neuromodulation: A single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) is delivered with a hand-held device (FDA approved) that creates a fluctuating magnetic field which triggers an electric current that modifies cortical excitability.

No role in prophylaxis :

  • Calcium channel blockers: Verapamil, nimodipine, diltiazem. 
  • α2 adrenergic agonist: Clonidine. 
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: Fluoxetine.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A doctor discharged a post-surgical patient without prescribing any antibiotics and wound dressing. The patient applied cow dung to the wound every day despite being advised to avoid contamination. After a week, the patient was admitted with septic shock. The patient's attenders sued the doctor for negligence. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence based on ______.
questions.solution:
The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence based on the avoidable consequence rule. 

Avoidable consequence rule is a limitation to contributory negligence in which the negligence of the patient aggravated damage caused by the already negligent act of the doctor. The aggravation of the damage could be avoided if the patient was not negligent afterwards. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence in such cases.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. The patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

Defenses against negligence:

  • No duty is owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata- If a court has already decided on a negligent case, the patient is not allowed to contest the same question in another proceeding based on the same set of facts. The patient can only make an appeal.
  • Res indicata- A negligent suit can be filed within 2 years of the alleged negligent act

Option A- Good Samaritan doctrine is also a part of contributory negligence where a person assisting another person who is in grave danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence unless the assistance is reckless.

Option B- Medical maloccurrence is a defense against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite of proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Option C- Last clear chance doctrine is a limitation to contributory negligence in which the doctor fails to prevent the damage caused by the negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to avoid the damage. The doctor will not be able to plead contributory negligence in such cases.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with a weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. Indirect laryngoscopy shows the following finding. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscle(s)?
questions.solution:
The indirect laryngoscopy image shows a keyhole appearance which is seen in phonasthenia. It is caused by the weakness of both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap visualized by indirect laryngoscopy. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

    • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space

This condition is treated by voice rest and vocal hygiene.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was brought by her relatives with complaints of insomnia, agitation, and restlessness. She was yelling about how the world is going to end and she has been assigned to save everyone. She had a history of multiple similar episodes in the past. Which of the following neurotransmitters is least likely to be involved in her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mania. Glutamate is least likely to be inolved in the pathogenesis of mania. Glutamate is more commonly involved in the mediation of neurocognitive effects of severe recurrent depression.

Norepinephrine and serotonin are the most commonly implicated neurotransmitters in the pathophysiology of mood disorders.

Dopamine has been shown to play a significant role in the development of mania.

The defining characteristics of mania are increased talkativeness, rapid speech, decreased need for sleep racing thoughts, distractibility, increase in goal-directed activity, and psychomotor agitation.

Some other hallmarks of mania are elevated or expansive mood, mood lability, impulsivity, irritability, and grandiosity.

In general, a manic patient should be treated with both a medication that alleviates acute mania, such as olanzapine, risperidone, or haloperidol, and also a medication for stabilization to prevent future mood episodes, such as lithium or valproic acid.

Psycho-education and psychotherapy are powerful long-term tools for patients with bipolar disorder as well as for their families or caregivers. In-depth, insight-oriented psychotherapy is not an appropriate treatment for mania.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of an indirect hernia. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

The contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the internal inguinal ring obliquely towards the external inguinal ring and then reaches the scrotum. Whereas, the contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medially to the inferior epigastric artery and the internal inguinal ring.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used to repair a hernia are:

Bassini repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendons to the inguinal ligament. 

Shouldice repair is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.

Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia

McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.

Stoppa-Rives repair is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.

Herniotomy is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

questions.text: An adolescent girl presents with the complaint of dropping objects from her hands during morning hours and during exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning with preserved consciousness. questions.text: An unimmunized boy developed conjunctivitis and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa. Four days later, he developed a rash over his trunk which became widespread. Which of the following would be the inclusion bodies formed by the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The inclusion bodies formed by the measles virus are Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleate giant cells that are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients infected with measles.

The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

The image given below shows the Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.


Measles is an infection caused by Paramyxovirus which is a single-stranded lipid-enveloped RNA virus. It spreads 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of the rash through body secretions.

The clinical features are mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of premolars. 

The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso, and extremities and reaches the palms and soles.

The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but a serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies is also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis, etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunization. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunization coverage under one year of age for eradication.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient is in a starved state for the past 36 hours. The glycogen stores in her body have been completely exhausted, and lipolysis has begun to meet the energy requirements. Which of the following enzymes is required for the final step of beta-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Thiolase is the enzyme required for the final step of β-oxidation of fatty acids.

Thiolase (3-ketoacyl-CoA-thiolase) enzyme splits 3-ketoacyl-CoA  at the 2,3-position to form a molecule of acetyl CoA and new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original acyl-CoA molecule. The acetyl CoA so formed enters the citric acid cycle to eventually form ATP. The new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original re-enters the β-oxidation pathway.

Thiolase is also involved in ketogenesis, when two acetyl-CoA molecules produced via fatty acid breakdown, condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA by a reversal of the thiolase reaction.

Other options:

Option A -  Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation using one high energy phosphate and forming AMP and PPi.

Option B - Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. It is not involved in fatty acid oxidation.

Option D - Thiophorase is also known as a succinyl-CoA-acetoacetate-CoA transferase. This enzyme is involved in keto-lysis in extrahepatic tissues. Acetoacetate is activated to acetoacetyl CoA by thiophorase enzyme. The CoA is transferred from succinyl-CoA to form acetoacetyl- CoA.

                                           Thiophorase
Acetoacetate+Succinyl CoA ------------------> Acetoacetyl CoA + Succinate.

Note: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1) is also known as carnitine acyltransferase I,

questions.text: You are comparing the packed cell volume (PCV) obtained from an arterial and venous blood sample of the same patient. Why is PCV higher in venous blood?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit (PCV) of venous blood is normally 3% greater than that of the arterial blood because of 2 reasons:

  • Chloride shift
  • A small amount of fluid in the arterial blood returns via the lymphatics rather than the veins.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows typical brush-like conidiophores seen in Penicillium species.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

  • The hyphae are hyaline and septate.
  • They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.
  •  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides produce chains of asexual spores known as conidia.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus spp. has conidiophores with swollen rounded ends (vesicles) which bear the sterigmata, from which the conidia arise.

Option B: Fusarium spp. on lactophenol cotton blue stain shows small septate hyphae and produces phialides, which give rise to single-celled microconidia or large multi-cell sickle or fusiform-shaped macroconidia, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Scopulariopsis spp. causes onychomycosis, pulmonary infection, fungus ball, and invasive fungal disease in immunocompromised hosts. Microscopically, conidia are large, spherical, lemon-shaped, arranged in chains.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the outpatient department for the facial defect shown in the given image. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is not included in Millard's criteria to undertake surgical repair of this condition?

choices.text: Child's age should not exceed 10 months
Child should be minimum 10 weeks old

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. 

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for a cleft lip:

  • 10 pounds in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10 g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair is done by rotating the local nasolabial flaps. Cleft lip repair is preferably done between 3 to 6 months of age.

A cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors. 

A cleft palate can occur in the primary palate (anterior cleft) or in the secondary palate (posterior palate). A Complete cleft palate involves both the primary and secondary palate. An incomplete cleft palate involves only the secondary palate.  

In the bilateral complete cleft palate, a Y-shaped cleft is seen with gaps between the primary and secondary palate and between the two halves of the secondary palate. In addition, there is a bilateral cleft upper lip. 

 The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only 
 
 

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator used in the Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
Children below the poverty line is not a component of the Global Hunger Index.

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measured by indicators. 

Dimensions Indicators
Inadequate food supply Proportion of the population undernourished
Child mortality Under 5 mortality rate
Child undernutrition Wasting in children under 5 years
Stunting in children under 5 years

GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X Standardized CWA) + (1/6 X Standardized CST) + (1/3 X Standardized CM)

Where,

  • PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished
  • CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age
  • CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age
  • CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age.

The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was 27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient who works at a smelter presented with headache, fever, sweating, muscle pain, joint pains, and chest tightness and discomfort. He had returned to work only that morning after taking a long weekend off for Holi. He was symptomatically managed, and his condition improved remarkably within a couple of days. Which of the following substances is most likely to be implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Monday morning fever (Smelter shakes/ Brass chills/ Metal fume fever), which is used to describe the symptoms associated with zinc poisoning.

Symptoms of metal fume fever occur 4–24 hours after exposure to zinc oxide fumes. It presents as an influenza-like illness with headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains. Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term ‘Monday morning fever’. Zinc toxicity resembles malarial chills. Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome.

It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxide fumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur. The illness usually has a good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops. The pathogenesis is not known but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.

Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead, antimony, silver and aluminum, etc.

Other options:

In acute poisoning with phosphorus, the vomitus and stools will be luminous in the dark. The stools may give rise to faint fumes, constituting the smoky stool syndrome.

    • Red velvety appearance of the stomach
    • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of acute pancreatitis underwent an abdominal CT for visualization of the pancreas. CT scan revealed a pancreatic pseudocyst, as shown below. Which option correctly describes the patient's condition according to the Atlanta classification?
questions.solution:
According to the Atlanta classification, pancreatic pseudocyst refers to non-necrotic fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging follow-up of pancreatitis.

The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue and is not lined by epithelium. The patients may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis and biliary obstruction. They may present with abdominal pain and epigastric mass. 

CT is usually done for the evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Observation is the preferred treatment in cases where the size of the pseudocyst is 6 cm and is arising from the tail of the pancreas. Interventions are required when it is complicated with infection, large size causing mass effect, diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm, recurrence following the previous resection.

Treatment includes:

  • Open surgical debridement
  • Cystenterostomy
  • Endoscopic cyst-gastrostomy
  • Percutaneous drainage
  • Octreotide infusion (decreases the amount of pancreatic secretions)

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation:

  • Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (IEP):
    • APFC- acute peripancreatic fluid collection. Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst- non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotising pancreatitis:
    • ANC- acute necrotic collection. Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • WON- walled-off necrosis. Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves and arteries pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot?

choices.text: Deep peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery

questions.solution:
The answer is Option C- Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery.

The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:

  • Tibialis anterior tendon
  • Extensor hallucis longus tendon
  • Deep peroneal nerve
  • Extensor digitorum longus tendon
  • Peroneus tertius tendon

The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.

Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.text: A community health officer is assessing a healthcare facility under the scheme shown in the image below. Which of the following is the main objective of this scheme?

choices.text: To promote infection control practices in public health care facilities
To promote labor room quality and infrastructure
To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens
To improve the quality of care during the intrapartum and immediate postpartum period

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Kayakalp scheme. The main objective of the program is to promote cleanliness, hygiene, and infection control practices in public healthcare facilities. 

The Kayakalp scheme is a national initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

Other main objectives:

  • To incentivize and recognize public healthcare facilities that adhere to standard protocols of cleanliness and infection control
  • To instill a culture of ongoing assessment and review of performance related to hygiene, cleanliness, and sanitation
  • To create and share sustainable practices to improve cleanliness in public health facilities linked to positive health outcomes

Other options:

Option B- To promote labor room quality and infrastructure is the main objective of LaQshya, a program launched by the MoHFW. 

Option C- To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens belonging to the BPL category is the main objective of Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana, a scheme by the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment.

Option D- To improve the quality of care for mothers and newborns during the intrapatum and immediate postpartum period by strengthening the competency of care providers is the main objective of Dakshata, a program launched by the MoHFW.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent fever for the past 1 week. His CBC is given below:

Hemoglobin: 5.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count: 1,40,000 cells/mm3 

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/mm3

A review of peripheral smear confirms acute myeloid leukemia. Which of the following cytogenetic findings would indicate a poor prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Monosomy 7 is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The production of symptoms and signs of AML is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure-pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding, or epistaxis, as well as fever, which may be caused by infection or the disease.

In addition, patients with AML present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, including subcutaneous nodules or“blueberry muffin” lesions (especially in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratory findings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.

Prognostic implications of chromosomal abnormalities in AML are given below:

  • t(8;21); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
  • Inv(16) or t(16;16); CBFβ
  • NPM1 mutation
  • CEBPA mutation

Poor prognosis

  • t(6;9)
  • 5q-
  • del(7q)
  • complex karyotype (≥3 abnormalities)
  • Monosomy7

questions.text: A mother brings her baby to the clinic due to concern about the shape of the baby’s head. You are suspecting craniosynostosis. The premature fusion of which of the following sutures is seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The picture is suggestive of a child with scaphocephaly, which involves the premature fusion of the sagittal suture.

Premature fusion restricts the growth of the skull perpendicular to the affected suture; in this case, the growth of the width of the skull is affected. Compensatory skull growth occurs parallel to the affected suture in order to accommodate the growing brain; in this case, the growth of length of skull is increased.

Other deformities of the skull:

Deformity Suture involved
Anterior Plagiocephaly Respective side coronal suture
Posterior Plagiocephaly Respective side lambdoid suture
Deformation Plagiocephaly Positional skull flattening (without suture fusion)
Brachycephaly Bilateral Coronal suture
Trigonocephaly Metopic suture
Scaphocephaly Saggital suture

 

Craniosynostosis consists of premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, resulting in an abnormal head shape.

  • Primary craniosynostosis: It results from a primary defect of ossification.
  • Secondary craniosynostosis: It results from the failure of brain growth.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you observe a child with the abnormality seen in the image below. Which of the following risk factors would you suspect to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The image depicts caudal regression syndrome, which is associated with both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus in the mother.

This syndrome consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and/or the lumbar vertebrae. It occurs more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers (both preconceptionally and early in pregnancy) than in other infants although the exact mechanism is unclear. 

USG shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature ending abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. The iliac wings appear abnormally close to each other like a shield due to the absence of the sacral vertebra. There may be associated VACTREL anomalies as well.

Other options:

  • Folic acid deficiency either as a result of dietary deficiency or due to antifolate drugs is associated with neural tube defects such as myelomeningocele, cardiac defects, and oral clefts.
  • Maternal use of lithium leads to an Ebstein anomaly and macrosomia. Chest X-ray showing a box-shaped heart in Ebstein anomaly is shown below: 
  • Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome characterized by digital hypoplasia, microcephaly, oral clefts, and other craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the emergency room after he suffered a lower limb injury in a road traffic accident. To decide whether to save the limb, you calculate the Mangled Extremity Severity Score, which adds up to a score of 5. What would you infer from this?

choices.text: Patient should be reassessed after 6 hours

questions.solution:
A Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) of 6 or less is consistent with a salvageable limb.

MESS can help decide between amputation and limb salvage in crushing injuries.

Components of MESS: mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

The maximal total score is 11. A score of 6 or less is consistent with a salvageable limb. With a score of 7 or greater, amputation is the eventual result.

questions.text: A milk sample received by health care workers is to undergo a quality checking process. All the following tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization, except:
questions.solution:
All the given tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization except the methylene blue reduction test.

questions.text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.  

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse include

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
  • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

questions.text: Which of the following procedures requires the consent of both spouses?
questions.solution:
Artificial insemination by a donor (AID) requires the consent of both the wife and the husband. If the consent is not obtained from the husband, he can proceed to file a case against the doctor, as well as a divorce from his wife.

Other options:
Options A and D- Vasectomy and tubectomy are sterilization procedures that require the written consent of only the person undergoing the procedure.

Option C: Medical termination of pregnancy does not require the consent of the husband.
The consent of the woman is mandatory for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: An intern suspected pneumoperitoneum due to the presence of air beneath the right diaphragm in the chest x-ray image of a patient. To confirm, another x-ray with a left lateral decubitus view was taken, which showed no free intraperitoneal air. What is this characteristic finding known as?
questions.solution:
Chilaiditi sign refers to the anterior disposition of the colon and is found between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm. This condition simulates air under the diaphragm, and hence is also one of the causes of pseudopneumoperitoneum.

An erect x-ray might mislead into suspecting pneumoperitoneum, prompting urgent surgical intervention, which is not required. Either a contrast-enhanced CT or a left lateral decubitus radiograph may be taken to differentiate between Chiladiti syndrome and pneumoperitoneum. 

On the left lateral decubitus view, distended colonic loops with haustral markings suggest the air is present within the bowel and not outside. 

It is an anatomical variant. In most cases, the patients are asymptomatic and noticed as an incidental finding in the imaging studies.  Chilaiditi syndrome is when the above signs are present along with symptoms like abdominal pain or distension.

questions.text: Which among the following organisms show stately motility?
questions.solution:

After a detailed evaluation, he was prescribed the splint as shown in the image given below to correct the gait deformity. Which of the following fractures is responsible for the gait deformity for which he is being treated?

choices.text: Fracture of the lower third of tibia

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing an ankle-foot orthosis brace used for the treatment is suggestive of foot drop. It occurs due to common peroneal nerve injury, which is commonly caused by a fracture of the neck of the fibula.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula

It is treated using an ankle-foot orthosis brace - a type of orthotic used to support the foot and ankle in foot drop.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman died in the hospital 3 days after being admitted with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness of her body, along with slurring of speech. An autopsy showed the following finding in the brain. Upon performing histopathology of the tissue, it was found that the cells exhibited increased eosinophilia on the H&E staining. What is the reason for this finding?

[H-Hematoxylin & E-Eosin]

choices.text: Loss of cytoplasmic RNA, which binds to red dye—Eosin
Loss of cytoplasmic RNA, which binds to blue dye—Hematoxylin
Denatured cytoplasmic proteins binding to blue dye—Eosin
Denatured cytoplasmic proteins binding to red dye—Hematoxylin

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a stroke, leading to liquefactive necrosis of the brain. Increased eosinophilia on the H&E stain of necrosed tissue is due to loss of cytoplasmic RNA, which binds to blue dye—Hematoxylin.

In necrotic cells, increased eosinophilia (more red/ pinkish color)  is due to two factors:

  • Loss of cytoplasmic RNA, which binds to blue dye—Hematoxylin. Hence, there will be less blue (basophilic) in color as there is no RNA to bind to blue dye. 
  • Denatured cytoplasmic proteins bind to red dye—Eosin. Hence, there will be more red/pink (eosinophilic) color in the cell.

Eosin is red and hematoxylin is blue. So Options C and D are easily ruled out.

Liquefactive necrosis refers to cell death by enzymatic degradation. The brain contains microglial cells, which contain many enzymes. When these cells are broken down, they release these enzymes, resulting in liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea. Colonoscopy showed skip lesions in the terminal ileum and cecum, with cobblestone appearance and geographical ulcers. The obtained histopathology image is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Uveitis and erythema nodosum are extraintestinal manifestations
TH1  cells play a crucial role in pathogenesis
p-ANCA positivity is seen in majority of such cases
Strictures and fistulas are common complications

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with abdominal pain, chronic diarrhea, colonoscopy revealing skip lesions in the terminal ileum and cecum, and histopathology image of non-caseating granulomas is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in a majority of individuals with ulcerative colitis, and only in a minority of patients with Crohn's disease.

The histopathological image shows transmural inflammation, where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted.

Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in 50% to 65% of individuals with ulcerative colitis but only 10% to 25% of those with Crohn's disease. In contrast, ulcerative colitis patients tend to lack antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which are often present in those with Crohn's disease.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following:

  • uveitis
  • migratory polyarthritis
  • sacroiliitis
  • ankylosing spondylitis
  • erythema nodosum
  • clubbing of the fingertips
  • primary sclerosing cholangitis (more frequent with ulcerative colitis)

Cutaneous granulomas form nodules that are referred to as metastatic Crohn disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with episodic facial flushing, dyspnea, and stridor. On examination, a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition is seen. The lower border of the swelling is not palpable. Chest x-ray shows the following finding. How will you manage this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of the Pemberton sign and the X-ray showing an intrathoracic mass are suggestive of a retrosternal goiter which is commonly managed by transcervical resection.

When the patient raises the arm above the shoulder level, retrosternal goiter compresses over the superior vena cava causing facial flushing and dilated veins over the neck and the chest wall. It may also compress the trachea causing stridor and dyspnea. This is called Pemberton’s sign. 

Retrosternal goiter is an extension of the nodular goiter into the mediastinum. This condition is usually asymptomatic and may not require surgery. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. 

Indications for surgery: 

  • Symptomatic patients
  • Significant airway compression
  • Young patients who may develop symptoms

Retrosternal goiters in elderly patients are commonly observed than treated. 

A majority of retrosternal goiters can be removed through the transcervical approach.

Retrosternal goiters that might lead to an open sternotomy approach:

  • Malignant cases.
  • Revision cases.
  • Goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum.
  • Diameter of the goiter exceeding that of the thoracic inlet.
  • Goiters that reach the carina.
  • Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch.

If the gland is fixed and immobile or too large to deliver through a cervical approach, a midline sternotomy is performed and the gland can be dissected from below to achieve a safe total thyroidectomy.

Other options:

Observation can be done for incidental asymptomatic patients.

Stridor resulting from compression of tracheobronchial tree by retrosternal goiter usually remains difficult to be relieved by tracheostomy.

Sistrunk operation is performed for thyroglossal fistula.

questions.text: A construction worker was brought to the casualty following a fall from a height. He was found to have bleeding in the nose and ears. Bluish-black bruises were found under the eyes. The following finding was seen behind the ears. What is the most likely type of skull fracture associated?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of fall from a height causing bleeding through the nose and ears, with bluish-black bruises under the eyes and behind the ears, is highly suggestive of basilar skull fracture or ring fracture.

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa (petrous part of temporal bone). 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

The image below shows raccoon eyes.

The image below shows battle's sign

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: The anti-cancer drug that can cross blood-brain barrier is ______.
questions.solution:
Lomustine can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Lomustine belongs to a class of nitrosoureas anti-cancer drugs. They are highly lipophilic and can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Anti-cancer drugs that can cross the blood-brain barrier:

  • Nitrosoureas: Lomustine, carmustine, semustine
  • Procarbazine
  • Temozolomide

Nitrosoureas cause interstrand DNA cross-linking, which is responsible for the cytotoxicity of the tumor. The use of nitrosoureas is presently limited to brain tumors due to their lipophilicity. They are effective in meningeal leukemia and brain tumors.

Side effects of nitrosoureas include profound and delayed myelosuppression. They are also highly carcinogenic and mutagenic. 

Apart from this, streptozocin is another nitrosourea compound that has a high affinity for islets of Langerhans.

questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. Which among the following statements is false about recording his dying declaration?

choices.text: The doctors role is to ascertain compos mentis
Dying declaration can be recorded only by the magistrate
Dying declaration has to be recorded in patient's words
Suggestions or leading questions are not allowed

questions.solution:
A dying declaration can be recorded by the doctor himself in the presence of two witnesses if he thinks that the victim will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate.

A dying declaration is a statement, verbal or written made by a victim before his or her death, relating to the circumstances leading to death. A medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded as soon as the severely injured person is brought to the hospital.

The doctors can record it themselves in the presence of two witnesses if they think that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. Treatment should not be delayed while recording a dying declaration.

The doctor has to ascertain that the dying person is of sound mind (compos mentis) before recording the statement.

If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained up to that point. It should be recorded in the patient's own words. No suggestions or leading questions are allowed, and any outsider is not allowed to be present.

After completing the writing, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it with a signature or thumb impression. The signature of two witnesses is mandatory.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin). Incomplete infection eradication leads to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA (>4 ng/mL) may be present due to prostate inflammation. 

Symptoms include fever, chills, malaise, painful micturition, perineal heaviness, rectal irritation, and pain on defecation. Urinary frequency may occur if the infection involves the bladder.

Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance of bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, a suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient was treated with haloperidol for delirium. He then developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, and muscle stiffness and showed agitation and an altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The abovementioned clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol are suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening adverse effect to antipsychotics with a predilection in males. Young patients are affected more commonly than elderly patients. Haloperidol poses the highest risk for NMS.

NMS is characterized by increased pulse and blood pressure; motor and behavioral symptoms such as muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, and agitation; and autonomic symptoms like hyperthermia. Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatine phosphokinase, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria.

The condition may occur within 24–72 hours after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Treatment includes the administration of dantrolene, bromocriptine, and sometimes, amantadine. Bromocriptine and amantadine pose direct DRA effects and may serve to overcome the antipsychotic-induced dopamine receptor blockade. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) has also been used for its management.

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, which can raise plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with symptoms in order of appearance - diarrhea, restlessness; extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, rapid fluctuations in vitals; myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity; and eventually delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is the most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol presents as a typical anaphylactic reaction with angioedema, facial and laryngeal edema, rash, urticaria, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

questions.text: During your evening rounds in the ICU, you notice that the capnograph of a patient on controlled ventilation is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely cause that you would suspect?
questions.solution:
The given capnograph shows clefts in the plateau phase of expiration known as curare clefts. This indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient.

The plateau phase of expiration in a capnograph represents the CO2 level in the air expired from the alveoli. During spontaneous breathing efforts, the patient might take inspiration which is not in sync with the controlled ventilation. This causes a decreased CO2 level which is seen as a dip/cleft in the capnograph.

This scenario might be seen when the patient is coming out of the effect of the neuromuscular blockade which is given to facilitate mechanical ventilation and to prevent patient-ventilator dys-synchrony.

Capnography is the quantitative method used to assess ventilation during the perioperative period. It provides a graphic representation of CO2 concentrations as a function of time or volume.

A normal time capnograph displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases, with the expiratory phase divided into three distinct components as shown in the image below:

I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor

questions.text:
A 6-day-old girl is brought by her parents with complaints of increased irritability, poor feeding, and three episodes of seizures. A lumbar puncture is performed and the findings are listed below. Which of the following is a suitable empirical treatment option?

Appearance: Turbid
Opening pressure: 30 cm H2O
WBC count: 1000 cells/µL (90% PMNL)
Glucose level: 35 mg/dL
Protein level:  80 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal meningitis. E. coli > Streptococcus agalactiae are the most likely causative organism of neonatal meningitis. Ampicillin + 3rd-generation cephalosporin is a suitable empirical treatment option as the age of the baby is less than a month.

Neonatal meningitis is classified as either early or late-onset. Early-onset meningitis within the first 72 hours of life. Late-onset meningitis is seen in premature infants and is generally caused by Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella. 

Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity. This makes them prone to meningitis and sepsis. Thus, an infant with a fever who is 28 days or younger, should be evaluated for sepsis. This is done by obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), differential blood count, blood culture, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture. 

Meningococcal infections are usually asymptomatic. If invasive disease occurs, then the clinical spectrum varies widely from meningococcal meningitis (highest proportion) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. It is predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. It is predominantly meningitic form.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child brought by his mother has a history of passing hard stools and straining during defecation. On examination, the lower abdomen feels hard on palpation. All of the following can be used in this child, except _______.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests the features of constipation. All the drugs mentioned above can be used for the treatment of constipation except loperamide.

Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent. It acts on peripheral μ-opioid receptors and also has mild anticholinergic properties.

It is used in non-infective diarrhea or diarrhea associated with AIDS. It should not be used in acute infective diarrhea because it inhibits the clearance of toxins or infective organisms. 

It is contraindicated in children less than 2-4 years of age because of serious complications of toxic megacolon. It poorly penetrates the CNS and does not have abuse liability.

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusate (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented to the emergency room with a progressive painful and pruritic rash covering his entire body as shown in the image below. DNA analysis from tissue samples for T-cell receptors (TCR) showed clonal rearrangements of the T-cell receptor genes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with the image showing fine, scaly, erythematous plaques and DNA analysis showing clonal arrangements of T cell receptor genes, is suggestive of mycosis fungoides.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ helper T cells), which usually stays confined to the skin. It usually involves the limb/girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area. It can disseminate into the blood, which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Analysis of the TCR gene for clonal rearrangements is now a standard approach for Mycosis fungoides, which has diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic implications. It is a marker of a monoclonal T-cell population. 

Histological hallmarks include:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells: cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded or hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses: tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism: invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.

The image given below shows histological markers seen in Mycosis fungoides:

Other options: 

Option A: Follicular mucinosis is a condition characterized by the deposition of mucin in the sebaceous glands. It presents as papules and well-demarcated lesions. However, it is not characterized by clonal arrangements of T cells. 

Option B: Bowen's disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia. However, it does not have clonal arrangements of T cells. 

Option C: Psoriasis is a condition that presents as salmon-coloured lesions with a silvery plaque and presents on the extensor surfaces. This patient's lesions are all over his body, making it unlikely.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of hearing voices that are asking him to end his life for the past 3 weeks. He speaks in sentences that do not make complete sense. On further probing, he reveals that recently, he had witnessed losing his friend in an accident. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of auditory hallucinations and disorganized speech for the past 3 weeks in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event, a provisional diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder can be made. The presence of these symptoms for less than one month and a history of a traumatic event are the clinchers for this diagnosis. 

A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day and is followed by a complete remission within a month of the appearance of the symptoms. There may also be a precipitating stressor like a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, according to DSM-5, requires the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

According to ICD-11, this is classified as acute and transient psychotic disorder (ATPD), and the duration of the episode does not last for more than 3 months.

The diagnosis is usually anticipatory or retrospective, after ruling out other mental health disorders and substance abuse. Relapses are seen due to a lack of adherence to medication and should be monitored on a long-term basis. Management of the episode involves hospitalization and initiation of psychotherapy along with pharmacotherapy. Second-generation antipsychotics are considered the first-line treatment option, while benzodiazepines can be used to manage the symptoms in an agitated patient.

Other options:

Option A. When a manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia, with a minimum of 2 weeks of delusions or hallucinations without mood abnormalities, schizoaffective disorder is the appropriate diagnosis.

Option C. A diagnosis of Schizophrenia, which has a similar presentation of psychotic symptoms, requires the continuous presence of these symptoms for a period of at least 6 months.

Option D. Schizophreniform disorder differs from a brief psychotic disorder in that the symptoms have a duration of at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are radiosensitive?
  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Ewing’s sarcoma
  3. Adamantinoma
  4. Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
Ewing’s sarcoma and multiple myeloma are radiosensitive tumors.

All malignant primary bone tumors are radioresistant, except small blue cell tumors like:

  • Multiple myeloma
  • Lymphoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

All carcinomas metastatic to bone are radiosensitive, except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant.

questions.text: Given below is an image depicting one of the mechanisms by which secretions are poured out of cells. Which of the following is an example of the glands that utilize this mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the apical part of the cells being shed off to discharge the secretion, which is the mechanism of apocrine secretion. This mechanism is seen in axillary sweat glands.

Exocrine glands can be classified into three subtypes by the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells.

Apocrine - In these glands, the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. Examples of apocrine glands are :

  • Secretion of milk fat by mammary glands
  •  Atypical sweat glands in the axilla, perianal region, periumbilical skin, mons pubis, etc.

Apocrine glands are large glands found in the dermis or subcutaneous fat. They are a type of sweat gland. It consists of a basal secretory coil followed by a straight duct that opens into the pilary canal above the duct of the sebaceous gland. In hairless skin, it directly opens onto the skin surface. 

Ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands

Each coil is lined by cuboidal cells with its apex projecting into the lumen and the base in contact with myoepithelial cells. These cells contain vacuoles, vesicles, and dense granules of varying sizes and pour their secretions as described above.

Apocrine activity is minimal before puberty, after which it is androgen-dependent and responsive to emotional stimuli. It is controlled by adrenergic nerves and is sensitive to adrenaline and noradrenaline.

The secretion is initially sterile and odorless, but it undergoes bacterial decomposition to generate odorous and musky compounds. Obstruction of apocrine sweat ducts and associated upper hair follicles in the axillae, breast areolae, and pubic region, mainly in women, is thought to cause Fox–Fordyce disease. It is also implicated in the causation of a painful, occasionally debilitating condition called hidradenitis suppurativa.

The given image shows an illustration of apocrine secretion.

Merocrine is the most common secretory mechanism. In this subtype, the secretions are initially packed into membrane-bound vesicles, shifted to the cell surface, and poured out by exocytosis. The cell remains intact. The stimulus for secretion is predominantly by raised intracellular calcium. An example of the merocrine gland is the simple sweat glands of the skin. An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

In holocrine glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion, and the secretion is poured commonly into an adjacent hair follicle. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands. A few examples of sebaceous glands are:

  • Montgomery's glands of nipples
  • The inner surface of prepuce, clitoris, and labia minora
  • Meibomian glands - palpebral tarsal glands

An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

Related Pearl: Fox-Fordyce disease

Fox Fordyce disease, also known as Apocrine Miliaria, is characterized by intensely pruritic, white pearly papules in apocrine areas. It most commonly involves axilla, then areolae. It is commonly seen in women (90%).

The condition occurs as a result of apocrine sweat duct occlusion by aggregates of epithelial cells of the apocrine or apoeccrine secretory cells. The earliest pathological sign is a small vesicle in the apocrine duct.

Later, the apocrine glands are seen to be enlarged, and as a consequence of repeated inflammatory events, perifollicular xanthomatosis with perifollicular foam cells expressing CD68 may develop.

Treatment:

First-line

  • Topical or intralesional steroids
  • Topical clindamycin lotion
  • Topical retinoids

Second line

  • Ultraviolet light
  • Oral retinoids

Third line

  • Surgery

This should not be confused with Fordyce spots or Fordyce disease which is due to ectopic sebaceous glands.

Image: Fox-Fordyce disease of the axilla

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic-range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. The image below shows the appearance of a renal biopsy specimen stained with Congo red and visualized under polarized light. Accumulation of which fibril protein will majorly be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has multiple myeloma. The major fibril protein accumulated in this patient is amyloid light chain (AL).

The above clinical scenario of backache, proteinuria with Bence-Jones protein, hypercalcemia are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The image showing a Congo red–stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy is indicative of amyloid accumulation in the organ. In multiple myeloma, the amyloid is made from the light chain of immunoglobulins (chiefly λ type). 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The abnormal fibrils are obtained by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind to proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Microscopy:

All types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils and are demonstrated on electron microscopy. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on x-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. The stain used for amyloid deposits is Congo red staining. It imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light. Under polarized microscopy, Congo red-stained amyloid shows apple-green birefringence.

Other options:

Option A -  The fibrillar protein amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) is accumulated in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis in chronic renal failure.

Option B -The fibrillar protein amyloid-associated (AA) is accumulated in secondary systemic amyloidosis and familial Mediterranean fever.

Option D - The fibrillar protein amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) is accumulated in the mutated form in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathies and in an unmutated form in systemic senile amyloidosis.
