questions.text:
A child presents with seizures and infantile spasms to the pediatric outpatient. Her mother gives a history of DPT vaccination 2 days back. Under which of the following categories would you classify this adverse effect following immunization?

DPT : diptheria-pertussis-tetanus
questions.solution:
The occurrence of seizures and infantile spasms following the administration of the DPT vaccine is classified as a vaccine product–related reaction.

Adverse effects following immunization (AEFI) are defined as any untoward medical occurrence which follows immunization and which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the usage of the vaccine. It can present as an unfavorable or unintended sign, abnormal laboratory finding, symptom, or disease.

In the given scenario, the onset of a seizure and infantile spasms are known side effects due to the inherent property of the pertussis component of the DPT vaccine. Hence, they are classified as vaccine product-related reaction AEFI.

Revised cause-specific categorization of AEFI as given by the WHO:

1. Vaccine product–related reaction - AEFI is caused or precipitated by a vaccine due to one or more of the inherent properties of the vaccine product.

2. Vaccine quality defect–related reaction - AEFI is caused or precipitated by a vaccine that is due to one or more quality defects of the vaccine product, including its administration device as provided by the manufacturer. Example - failure by the manufacturer to completely inactivate a lot of inactivated polio vaccines leading to cases of paralytic polio (Option A)

3. Immunization error–related reaction - AEFI is caused by inappropriate vaccine handling, prescribing, or administration and thus is preventable. Example- the transmission of infection by a contaminated multidose vial (Option C)

4. Immunization anxiety–related reaction - An AEFI arising from anxiety about the immunization. Example - vasovagal syncope in an adolescent during/following vaccination (Option D)

5. Coincidental event - AEFI is caused by something other than the vaccine product, immunization error, or immunization anxiety. Example - a fever occurring at the same time as the vaccination (temporal association), but is, in fact, caused by another disease such as malaria

Vaccine product-related reactions and vaccine quality defect-related reactions are together known as vaccine reactions.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with corneal opacity, deficiency of which of the following could be a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Keratan sulfate I is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency. Hence, its deficiency can lead to corneal opacity.

Keratan sulfate is made of repeating units of N-acetyl glucosamine and galactose. Two types of keratan sulfate are seen:

  • Keratan sulfate I - in the cornea
  • Keratan sulfate II - in the cartilage

Dermatan sulfate (DS) also plays a role in corneal transparency. However, DS is widely distributed in the body, mainly in the skin.

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. 

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:

  • Rectal bleeding
  • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea
  • Pain or difficulty in defecation
  • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids
  • Rectal prolapse.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient who had undergone cataract surgery previously is noted to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding noted in the image above is Soemmering's ring, which is one of the types of after-cataract.

After-cataract is the most common postoperative complication encountered following cataract surgery. Soemmering's ring is defined as a thick ring of after-cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction.

No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear. If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

The image given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius' ring is a small ring shaped pigment on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule that occurs following blunt trauma.

Option C: Weiss' or Vogt’s ring is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with mental confusion and muscle cramps. The results of his ABG analysis fall under the marked area 'C' in the acid-base nomogram given below. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The image shows the acid-base nomogram, which is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH. The area marked C corresponds to alkaline pH with elevated HCO3- levels, suggesting metabolic alkalosis. This may have been a result of hypokalemia, given that this patient has muscle cramps and altered mental status.

 

Causes of metabolic alkalosis include:

1. Loss of hydrogen ions:

  • Removal of gastric secretions, such as in vomiting or gastric aspiration
  • Gastrocolic fistula
  • Bartter's, Gitelman's, and Liddle syndromes
  • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary hyperaldosteronism, Cushing's syndrome)

2. H+ movement into cells: Hypokalemia

3. Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of exogenous alkali
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Milk-alkali syndrome

3. Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume): loop or thiazide-type diuretics

questions.text: When the value of Reynold’s number is 2500, the flow is said to be _______.
questions.solution:
Reynold’s number  Type of blood flow
<2000 Laminar
2000-3000 Transitional
>3000 Turbulent

Turbulent blood Flow:

The probability of turbulence is related to the velocity, diameter of the vessel, and viscosity of the blood. This probability can be expressed by Reynold’s formula.

  • Re - Reynolds number
  • v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
  • ρ – density of blood
  • D – diameter of the vessel in cm
  • µ – viscosity of blood in poise

The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number.

In the proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery, Reynold’s number can rise to several thousands during the rapid phase of the ejection, which causes considerable turbulence due to the following:

  • High velocity of blood flow
  • Pulsatile nature of the flow
  • Sudden change in vessel diameter
  • Large vessel diameter

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with right scrotal swelling and pain. On examination, transillumination is positive, and cough impulse is absent. His condition is due to the accumulation of fluid in which layer of the testis?

questions.text: A patient was advised to take green leafy vegetables as a natural dietary source of vitamin K. Which is the compound that acts as the source of vitamin K in these vegetables?

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist for a regular ophthalmic check-up. He has no ocular complaints. His vision is 6/12 in both eyes. His ophthalmic finding is given below. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing a circumferential greyish white corneal band with limbal sparing is suggestive of arcus lipoides/ arcus senilis/ Gerontoxon.

Arcus senilis (AS) is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma.

  • Deposition begins at the superior and inferior aspects and progresses to encircle the entire peripheral cornea which is about 1 mm wide.
  • Peripheral border of this ring opacity is sharp while central border is diffuse.
  • The exterior border of AS and the limbus is separated by a clear zone of the cornea called the interval of Vogt (limbal sparing).

Other options:

Option A: The Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring is a dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in the Descemet membrane. It is classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 

The images given below show Kayser–Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract respectively seen in Wilson's disease.

Option C: Limbus sign is caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a milky precipitate at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.

Option D: Vogt’s white limbal girdle is a degenerative change seen frequently in elderly people. It appears as bilateral chalky white crescentric opacities in the interpalpebral area both nasally and temporally. Limbal sparing may or may not be there.

Note: Pseudo-gerontoxon is a greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS. It is seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with numbness in her hands, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability. She had undergone a gastrectomy recently and she looks very pale. Her peripheral smear findings are shown below. If the condition is left untreated, which of the following will be seen?

choices.text: Large-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of proprioception
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of temperature sense
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of vibration sense

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of numbness, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability suggest anemia. The history of gastrectomy and the peripheral smear showing large hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes depicting macrocytic anemia is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient is at risk of developing large-fiber neuropathy causing loss of proprioception.

Vitamin B12 deficiency typically leads to large-fiber neuropathy, which presents with loss of vibration and loss of proprioception. Small nerve fibers are spared in B12 deficiency.

Pernicious anemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. The other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency are gastrectomy, gastric bypass surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption of cobalamin from food, and so on.

The clinical features include easy fatiguability, numbness of hands, loss of vibration and proprioception, hyperreflexia, and loss of ankle reflexes. 

Investigations reveal anemia, macrocytosis, and reduced cobalamin levels. Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated. Antibodies to the intrinsic factor may be seen in pernicious anemia.

Peripheral smear shows marked variation in red cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis). The presence of red cells that are macrocytic and oval (macro-ovalocytes) is highly characteristic. Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules, instead of the normal three to four.

Treatment can vary according to the regimen. One regimen consists of intramuscular injections of 1000 micrograms of cyanocobalamin weekly for a month, and then monthly thereafter.  

Note: Small-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small-fiber neuropathies present with temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

Related Pearl: Nerve Fiber Types And Sensory Neuropathies

  • Pyridoxine toxicity
  • Cisplatin neuropathy

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after he collapsed on the dance floor. The findings of a 12-lead ECG taken at the emergency room are shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs could have precipitated the associated condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of torsades de pointes. Among the given options, cisapride is most likely to have precipitated this condition.

Cisapride is a prokinetic agent. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism aided by weak 5-HT3 antagonism.

At high concentrations, cisapride blocks delayed rectifying K+ channels in the heart which prolongs Q-Tc interval and predisposes to torsades de pointes/ ventricular fibrillation.

The illustration given below shows the ECG findings of torsades de pointes.

Other options:

Option A: Domperidone can cause galactorrhea, gynecomastia, amenorrhea, or impotence.

Option B: Metoclopramide can cause dystonias, parkinsonian-like symptoms, and tardive dyskinesia. Extrapyramidal effects occur more commonly in children.

Option D: Adverse effects of omeprazole include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and accelerated osteoporosis in the elderly.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl presents with the finding shown below. She has a history of multiple similar episodes in the past and reports that some of her family members have similar complaints. She has no itching. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This girl presents with features of hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is due to a deficiency of C1 inhibitor. 

Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder that is more common than complement deficiency states. A deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin. It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

Note -

  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - collagen vascular disorders.
  • C5-C8 deficiency - recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon that has worsened over the past 6 months. She noticed hard whitish bumps over her thumb, as shown in the image. She also reports joint pains involving her hands and wrists and difficulty in swallowing solid food. On examination, there is a hardening of the skin of the hands with claw-like appearance. Laboratory study reveals high titers of anticentromere antibodies. What is the most likely condition involving her hands?
questions.solution:
Calcinosis cutis is a condition in which calcium salts are deposited in the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The combination of calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, is termed CREST syndrome. This syndrome is a variant of systemic sclerosis.

Dystrophic calcification is the most common cause of calcinosis cutis and is associated with normal laboratory values of calcium and phosphorus. It may involve the skin, subcutaneous, and soft tissues and occur in about 40% of the patients, most commonly seen in patients with long-standing anti-centromere antibody-positive limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).

The calcific deposits are composed of calcium hydroxyapatite crystals and vary in size from small punctate lesions to large masses. The deposits usually occur in tissues damaged due to inflammation, hypoxia, and local trauma. They can be visualized on plain radiography and dual-energy CT.

Calcinosis cutis is commonly seen over the finger pads, palms, extensor surfaces of the forearms, and the olecranon and prepatellar bursae. The lesions cause pain and nerve compression. They may ulcerate through the skin, cause drainage of chalky-white material, and lead to secondary infections.

questions.text: A young boy who is a known case of Klinefelter's syndrome presents with a painless scrotal swelling and precocious puberty. After an initial ultrasound that revealed a testicular mass, surgical removal was done. The specimen was sent for histopathological analysis; the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the biopsy findings points towards the diagnosis of a Leydig cell tumor.

Development of a painless testicular mass in a child with a history of Kleinfelter's syndrome and precocious puberty is suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor like Leydig cell tumor. The biopsy shows large polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm. The cytoplasm also shows rod-shaped crystals referred to as "crystalloids of Reinke" which confirms the diagnosis.

Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. Leydig-cell tumors are associated with:

  • Kleinfelter's syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma syndrome caused by germline mutations in the enzyme fumarate hydratase.

It appears as a homogenous golden-brown tumor, that is usually less than 5cm. On microscopy, round or polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm are seen. In about 25% of the patients, the cytoplasm contains crystalloids of Reinke as shown below:


Other options:

Option B - Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome. On microscopy, tumor cells are arranged in trabaculae to form cord-like structures and tubules as shown below:


Option C - Yolk-sac tumor is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis also known as endodermal sinus tumor. They secrete α-fetoprotein. On microscopy, a typical lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, is seen. In half the cases, a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells is present known as Schiller-Duval bodies as shown below:


Option D - Seminoma testis is the most common germ cell tumor. They present as large bulky tumors, without any hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopy, seminoma cells are round to polyhedral and have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli as shown below:

questions.text: The action of 5-lipo-oxygenase (5-LOX) on arachidonic acid (AA) produces a potent non-cysteinyl factor that plays a role in the chemotaxis and adhesion of neutrophils. What is this factor?
questions.solution:
LTB4 is a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils that causes the aggregation and adhesion of the cells to venular endothelium, generation of ROS, and release of lysosomal enzymes.

The cysteinyl-containing leukotrienes LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 cause intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm (important in asthma), and increased permeability of venules.

Leukotrienes are more potent than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchospasm.

questions.text: A dentist presents with painful lesions on his fingertip as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely etiology for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing vesicles and cloudy blisters at the pulp of fingers is suggestive of herpetic whitlow. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Herpetic whitlow is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions. Clinical features include painful deep vesicles at the site of inoculation (in this case fingertips) which coalesce to form large bullae or a honeycomb appearance. Fever and constitutional symptoms are mild.

Whitlow can lead to necrosis of the distal 4/5th of the terminal phalanx. It does not cause necrosis of the entire phalanx because the proximal 1/5th escapes as in this part the artery does not cross the fibrous septa.

The pulp space of fingers contains subcutaneous fat arranged in tight compartments. These compartments are formed by fibrous septa extending from the skin to the periosteum of the terminal phalanx.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

  • Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)
  • Most definitive test- virus isolation using human diploid fibroblast in which cytopathic changes can be observed as early as 24 - 48 hours.
  • Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Intranuclear type A inclusion bodies may also be seen.

The image given below shows Tzanck cells.

Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Whitlow or pulp space infections are treated by a lateral incision and drainage. Its complications are: 

  • Ischemic necrosis of the distal 4/5th of terminal phalanx due to vessel occlusion.
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Flexor tenosynovitis
  • Septic arthritis of DIP (distal interphalangeal joint)

Other forms of inoculation type of herpes are:

  • Herpes gladitorium in wrestlers where vesicles can be present on the scalp, face, and upper trunk
  • Scrumpox is seen in rugby players due to facial contact.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching of the skin of the leg. On examination, the affected area is hyperpigmented and atrophic, with a non-tender subcutaneous nodule over the shin. The causative organism is suspected to be linked to blackflies. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The patient with hyperpigmentation, atrophic and itchy lesion, and a non-tender subcutaneous nodule over the shin, and in whom blackflies are suspected to be involved, is likely to be infected with Onchocerca volvulus. 

Onchocerca volvulus is a tissue nematode. The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae.

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus.

The larvae penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues. They may be seen within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or may live freely in the tissues.

The adult worm can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

Other options:

Option A: Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors. The microfilariae develop into third-stage larvae in the vector, which is the infective form.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Loa loa.


Option B: Leishmania donovani completes its life cycle in the female sandfly, the vector, and in definitive hosts which include man, dogs, and other mammals. The promastigote form in the midgut of the sandfly is the infective form.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Leishmania donovani.


Option C: Wucheraria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Wucheraria bancrofti.

questions.text: A newborn developed cyanosis soon after birth. Chest x-ray showed the characteristic egg-on-a-string appearance, as shown in the below image. Which of the following options indicates the relation of the aorta with respect to the pulmonary artery in the given condition?

choices.text: Aorta lies posterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies posterior and to the right of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the right of pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an x-ray showing egg on a string appearance is characteristic of transposition of great arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta generally lies anterior and to the right of the Pulmonary artery. Therefore it is also referred as D-TGA.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A man sustained a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following toxins produced by the causative organism is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: The blood report of a patient shows increased uric acid levels. Which of the following diagnosis can be ruled out?
questions.solution:
Hyperuricemia is not seen in xanthinuria.

Xanthinuria occurs due to a defect in the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Xanthine oxidase catalyzes the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. It is associated with hypouricemia and xanthine lithiasis.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by complete deficiency of HGPRTase, whereas Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome is caused by the partial deficiency of HGPRTase. Purines accumulate, causing hyperuricemia.

In von Gierke's disease, the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate via the pentose phosphate pathway leads to increased production of ribose-5-phosphate which activates the de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides. Overproduction of these nucleotides leads to their degradation, which causes hyperuricemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of WHO's major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with panmyelosis

questions.solution:
Subnormal serum erythropoietin level is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera. The other three options are included as major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera.

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus. It is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm. The increase in the red cells is predominantly responsible for the clinical symptoms in this condition.

In 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years, there is increased myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of PCV:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Thrombocytosis - leads to venous arterial thrombosis, hepatic venous thrombosis. Erythromelalgia is the erythema, burning, and pain in the extremities. It also occurs due to thrombocytosis.
  • Erythrocytosis - leads to hyperviscosity, leading to neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and systolic hypertension. 
  • Aquagenic pruritis
  • Hyperuricemia and gout - It may occur due to the large turnover of the hematopoietic stem cells

Diagnosis: Criteria for diagnosis is given below:

Major criteria:

  1. Hb more than 16.5g/dL in males and 16g/dL in females or hematocrit of >49% in men and >48% in women
  2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  3. Presence of JAK-2 mutation

Minor criteria:

  • Subnormal erythropoietin levels.

Diagnosis requires all three major criteria or the first 2 major and 1 minor criterion.

Management:

  • Target Hb levels are < 14g/dL in males and < 12g/dL in females.
  • Periodic phlebotomy can be done to reduce hyperviscosity and to maintain the red cell mass. It is usually done at 3-month intervals.
  • Anticoagulants are given when there is thrombosis.
  • Allopurinol can be given to control hyperuricemia.
  • Ruxolitinib which is a nonspecific JAK2 inhibitor, pegylated IFN-α, or PUVA therapy can be used for intractable pruritis.
  • Ruxolitinib or pegylated IFN-α can be used to manage symptomatic splenomegaly.
  • Anagrelide which is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor is used to reduce platelet count in these patients.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

The population statistics of a country are being predicted. According to the Malthusian growth model, if a country's _______ is 2%, then the population will double in ______.

[Abbreviations: AGR-Annual growth rate, TFR-Total fertility rate]
questions.solution:
As per the Malthusian growth model, when the annual growth rate is 1%, the population doubles in 70 years. Therefore, when the annual growth rate is 2%, the population will double in 35 years.

The Malthusian growth model/ rule of 70:

Rating Annual growth rate Population doubles in
Slow growth <0.5% >139 years
Moderate growth from 0.5% ~139 years
Rapid growth from 1% 70 years
Very rapid growth from 1.5% approximately 50 years

Explosive growth from 3% 20-25 years

The growth rate of India is estimated at 1% as per 2020 UN data. Therefore, it falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth.

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot, which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitot spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 65-year-old obese woman presented with vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. She had recurrent episodes of such complaints for the past few days. An erect abdominal X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be related to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels, which indicates small bowel obstruction. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of gallstone ileus. Rigler’s triad is associated with this condition.

Rigler’s triad comprises of:

  1. Small bowel obstruction (multiple air-fluid levels)
  2. Pneumobilia (gas in the biliary tract)
  3. Atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gallstone)

Given below is a plain x-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. The most common site of blockage is the terminal ileum before entering the cecum. It usually presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, distention, and obstipation) in patients with a history of gallstones.

Large-sized gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation resulting in a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad.

The patient may have constant pain or recurrent episodic discomfort from the intestinal obstruction which may be incomplete. CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis. This condition is managed by laparotomy and milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction. The stone is tried to be crushed within the bowel lumen or the intestine is opened at that point to remove the gallstone.

Other options:

Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus. It comprises a sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain, recurrent retching with minimal vomitus and inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube.

Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

Note: Obstipation is the failure to pass both flatus and faeces.

questions.text: A primigravida with chronic hypertension delivers a small-for-gestational-age baby. Among the following options, what can be the likely percentile of the baby's weight?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the likely percentile of the weight of a small for gestational age baby is the 8th percentile.

Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age.

They are constitutionally small and nearly 70% of the babies falling under this category are not at any increased risk for adverse outcomes and will eventually attain normal growth patterns. The rest of the 30% are truly growth restricted and are at increased risk of morbidity and mortality. Thus, SGA is not universally associated with growth restriction.

With respect to birth weight percentile, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age.

Birth weight Terminology
<10th percentile Small for gestational age
>90th percentile Large for gestational age
Between the 10th and 90th percentile Appropriate for gestational age

 

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a deficiency of fetal growth and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR:

  • Insult on fetal growth occurs early.
  • As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.
  • It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

  • Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect.
  • The head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.
  • It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases.

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR, while late-onset maternal vascular disease (PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: While planning thrombolysis for a patient with MI, use of which of the following agents will reduce the chances of a dosing error?
questions.solution:
Tenecteplase is given as a single bolus dose (based on body weight) which reduces the rate of medication errors (common with IV infusions).

Tenecteplase and reteplase are referred to as bolus fibrinolytics as their administration does not require prolonged intravenous infusion.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents to the gynecology department with complaints of amenorrhea.  She had no history of cyclical abdominal pain, hormonal intake, radiation or chemotherapy, or any central nervous symptoms like visual disturbances or headaches. After a thorough physical examination, ultrasonography, karyotyping, and diagnostic laparoscopy, the diagnosis of Swyer syndrome was made. Which of the following is not congruent with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Normal development of the Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The karyotype of patients with Swyer syndrome (pure gonadal dysgenesis) is 46XY. The 45XO karyotype is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Swyer's syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene or another gene with a testis-determining effect such as DAX1, SF-1, or CBX2. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics due to absence of sex hormones.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and absence of secondary sex characters.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

  • Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation
  • As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.
  • Streak gonads may undergo malignant transformation and develop into germ cell tumors. Hence, they have to be removed prophylactically.
  • Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients
  • Genetic counseling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with hemoptysis and severe chest pain. After a few hours, the patient died due to a massive stroke. Autopsy of the lungs revealed pulmonary infarct, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true about the type of infarct?

choices.text: It is seen in tissues with dual circulation.
It occurs in solid organs with end arterial circulation.
As time passes, the infarction becomes progressively paler.

questions.solution:
The autopsy specimen of the lung shows hemorrhagic infarct (red infarct). A red infarct usually occurs in tissues with dual blood supply, such as the lungs. All other options are incorrect.

Pulmonary infarction may occur in patients as a result of pulmonary embolism (PE). The clinical features of PE mimic those of myocardial infarction, and the patient presents with severe chest pain, dyspnea, and shock. Some patients may also present with pleuritic pain, and cough. Emboli that lead to pulmonary infarction additionally cause fever and hemoptysis.

 An infarction is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either arterial supply or venous drainage.

  • The infarctions are usually wedge-shaped, with the occluded blood vessel forming the apex and the periphery of the organ, forming the base.
  • Fresh infarcts are poorly defined. Over a few days, the margins become better defined due to congestion caused by the inflammatory reaction surrounding the lesion.
  • Depending on the appearance, infarction may be either a red infarct or a white infarct. 

Red infarcts occur

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion).
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone.
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  • in tissues previously congested by a sluggish venous outflow.
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

The infarcts in the lung are almost always hemorrhagic. The extravasated red RBCs in the red infarct are phagocytosed by the macrophages, which convert the heme iron into hemosiderin. Over time, the infarction appears brown in color due to the accumulation of the hemosiderin-laden macrophages. 

The image below shows red infarct in the lung.

 

White infarcts:

  • They occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney).
  • It is seen in organs, where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.
  • In contrast to red infarct, the white infarcts tend to become paler as time passes.

The image below shows white infarcts in the spleen.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is being evaluated for decreased urine output. One week ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit with pneumonia. He was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including a third-generation cephalosporin and gentamicin. His vitals are now stable. The results of laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following types of casts would you find in this patient?

Hb%- 12 g/dL

WBC: 12,000 cells/μL;

         Neutrophils - 50%

         Lymphocytes- 40%

         Eosinophils- 2%

         Monocytes- 7%

         Basophils- 1%

Platelets : 200,000/μL

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 40 mg/dL

Serum creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL

Serum Na+: 133 mEq/L

Serum K+: 5.8 mEq/L

Serum Cl-: 108 mEq/L

Urinary protein: <1g/dL

FeNa: 2.2%
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of oliguria with increased serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is suggestive of acute kidney injury (AKI), probably following the use of gentamicin, a nephrotoxic drug. Muddy brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, which is a type of intrinsic renal failure. Tubular epithelial casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.

In this patient,

  • BUN/Creatinine ratio is 40/3.8 = 10.5:1 which is <15:1, and
  • Fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) is >1% 

Both these parameters are suggestive of intrinsic acute kidney injury.

Common causes of intrinsic AKI:

  • Acute glomerulonephritis
  • Tubulointerstitial diseases
  • Vasculitis
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome
  • Malignant hypertension

Tubulointerstitial diseases are caused due to ischemia, sepsis/infection, or nephrotoxins. Nephrotoxins can be exogenous or endogenous.

  • Exogenous nephrotoxins: Aminoglycosides, cisplatin, amphotericin-B, acyclovir, vancomycin, zoledronate, iodinated contrast
  • Endogenous nephrotoxins: Products of hemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, myeloma proteins

Laboratory findings in AKI due to acute tubular necrosis:

  • Acute kidney injury is associated with anemia, which is multifactorial in origin. Uremia leads to a reduction in platelet function, although the platelet count remains normal, thereby causing bleeding and leading to anemia.
  • AKI is typically associated with hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.
  • Damage to the tubular cells and interstitium leads to decreased reabsorption of Na+, which results in fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) of >1%. This patient has hyponatremia due to increased urinary Na+ excretion. 

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline casts are seen in patients with prerenal acute kidney injury. In prerenal AKI, BUN/Creatinine ratio is >20. Common conditions associated with prerenal AKI include hypovolemia; congestive heart failure; liver failure; and impaired renal autoregulation due to drugs like NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).

Option C: RBC casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis. This patient does not have hypertension or proteinuria to signify glomerular pathology.

Option D: WBC casts are seen in patients with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). A patient with AIN presents with fever, flank pain, rash, and arthralgia. Urinalysis shows sterile pyuria. CBC shows eosinophilia (not seen in this patient).

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A young man is arrested for rubbing his genitals against a female passenger to obtain sexual satisfaction in public transport. He is punishable under which section of the IPC/BNS?
questions.solution:
Obtaining sexual satisfaction by rubbing private parts against another person is known as frotteurism. This sexual offence is liable to punishment under Sec. 290 IPC (Sec 292 BNS) with a fine of up to 1000 rupees. 

They obtain sexual satisfaction through the action. It is generally done by rubbing against a female's breasts, buttocks, thighs, or genital areas in crowds. They feel that the touching behaviour will not offend and that the victims find it pleasurable. 

Other options:

Option A - Sec. 354-C IPC (Sec 77 BNS) deals with voyeurism. It is a sexual offence wherein the alleged offender (voyeur or peeping Tom) experiences sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is undressed and in the process of disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option C - Sec. 294 IPC (Sec 296 BNS) deals with obscene acts like exhibitionism where they obtain sexual gratification with intentional exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. It is punishable by imprisonment up to three months or a fine. 

Option D - Sec. 297 IPC (Sec 301 BNS) deals with offences related to trespassing of burial places. Necrophilia and necrophagia are punishable under this IPC. Necrophilia is defined as the desire for sexual intercourse with a corpse and in necrophagia, the person drinks the blood and eats the flesh of the victim to derive sexual pleasure.  It is punished with imprisonment up to one year and or fine.

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of various studies on the relationship between rabies infection and mortality rates are plotted as shown in the image below. What is this graphical representation known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a funnel plot, which is a means to assess the extent to which a systematic review is influenced by publication and other biases.

In general, there will be more variability in the results of smaller studies than larger studies, so, this plot should look like an inverted funnel. The larger study results cluster around the overall mean effect more closely than the results of the smaller studies. A funnel plot displays the effect size plotted against the sample size.

If the distribution of results of smaller studies is asymmetrical, it suggests that some smaller studies that showed unfavorable results may be missing from the analysis because of various biases. An asymmetrical funnel plot shows the apparent presence of publication bias. 

Other options :

Option B: Forest plots are commonly used to present the results of meta-analyses. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers.

The following image shows a generic forest plot showing the odds ratios of various studies, their confidence intervals, and the summary measure arrived at through meta-analysis.

Option C: Scattergram is a graphical representation of the bivariate distribution relationship between two correlated variables. Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. This is expressed in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient and its direction is indicated by the sign. 

The image below shows a scattergram.

Option D- An ogive is a cumulative frequency polygon that forms a typical S-shaped curve.

The following image shows an example of an ogive.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: In healthy and acclimatized young men who are exposed to high environmental temperatures, what is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with their normal physiology?
questions.solution:
A sweat excretion rate of 4.5 L/4 hours in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature. This is known as McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate.

This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined.

Zone of comfort    Predicted P4SR
Comfort zone 1–3 liters
Just tolerable 3–4.5 liters
Intolerable 4.5+ liters

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation for recurrent hemiparesis. The child has also had two episodes of seizures in the last six months. On examination, the child is short-statured. There is associated motor weakness. Laboratory examination shows lactic acidosis, and muscle biopsy appears as shown below with Gomori trichrome stain. What is the likely mode of inheritance of this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS). The patient presents in childhood, with classical features of hemiparesis and hemianopia, suggestive of stroke-like episodes. The histopathology of the muscle biopsy stained with Gomori-trichrome stain shows ragged red fibers. This disease has a mitochondrial inheritance.
 
In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.
 
The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:
The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.
 
The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
 
Therefore, the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.
 
Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.
  • There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 
  • The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction, called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.
  • Also, during a cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Some other clinical features of this condition are - 

  • Cortical blindness
  • Focal and generalized seizures
  • Recurrent migraine-like episodes and vomiting
  • Short stature
  • Hearing loss
  • Muscle weakness
  • The stroke like episodes in MELAS are characteristic because they do not respect vascular territories

A replapsing-remiting course is most common with stroke-like episodes leading to progressive neurologic dysfunction and dementia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was referred to a urologist following symptoms of hematuria, fever, and hypertension and the detection of a left-sided abdominal mass. On further investigation, he was diagnosed with Wilms tumor. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor of the tumor?

choices.text: Histology and stage of the tumor
Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.solution:
The histology and stage of the tumor are the most important prognostic factors of Wilms tumor. 

Wilms tumor/nephroblastoma is an embryonal renal neoplasm. It is usually diagnosed before the age of five. Wilms tumor is caused by abnormal renal development, resulting in the proliferation of the metanephric blastema.

Children may present with a mass abdomen, fever, and hematuria, which is indicative of the extension of the tumor into the renal pelvis. Hypertension is also observed in a considerable percentage of patients.

Prognostic factors for Wilms tumor:

  • Histology
  • Stage
  • Age
  • Tumor weight
  • Response to therapy
  • Loss of heterozygosity at 1p and 16q 

The two most important factors are the histology and the stage of the tumor.

Most of the tumors have favorable histology and are characterized as the “classic” type that consists of three components—blastemal, stromal, and epithelial (tubules) tissues. 

Unfavorable tumors are those with focal or diffuse anaplasia. Two principal staging systems are used:

  • The COG system is based on findings prior to the initiation of treatment. There exists a local stage and a disease stage. The local stage defines the extent of abdominal disease while the disease stage considers both local disease and metastasis. Metastasis commonly occurs in the lungs.
  • The SIOP classification is based on the histologic appearance of the tumors at resection and the outcomes. They are classified as completely necrotic (low risk), blastemal (high risk) and other histological types.

Imaging with USG abdomen and pelvis, CT scan, MRI etc., shows a solid space-occupying lesion in the kidney.

Management is mainly by chemotherapy and nephrectomy.

questions.text:
During the rainy season, a patient was diagnosed with dengue fever. What is the correct sequence of events occurring in this patient with respect to the fever?
  1. Hypothalamic set point lowered
  2. Shivering 
  3. Hypothalamic set point raised
  4. Sweating
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events during fever is 3→2→1→4.

During the onset of fever, the hypothalamic set point is raised by pyrogens. As the body is still at a lower temperature, various heat generating mechanisms are activated to match the hypothalamic temperature setpoint:

  • Shivering- the shivering center is located in the posterior hypothalamus. It is normally inhibited by signals from the heat center in the anterior hypothalamic-preoptic area but is excited by cold signals from the skin and spinal cord. A sudden increase in heat setpoint results in the activation of this center. It then transmits non-rhythmic signals through bilateral tracts through the lateral columns of the spinal cord, and finally to the anterior motor neurons. They increase the tone of the skeletal muscles throughout the body. As the tone rises above a certain critical level, shivering begins. During maximum shivering, body heat production can rise to four to five times normal.
  • Vasoconstriction (decreased blood flow to skin) is mediated by increased sympathetic drive by the activation of the posterior hypothalamic sympathetic center.
  • An increase in chemical thermogenesis in which heat production takes place in the brown fat by the mechanism of uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation. This is the predominant mechanism seen in neonates.

Later, the removal of pyrogens causing the resolution of the fever occurs which lowers the hypothalamic set point to lower than the body temperature. Hence various heat loss mechanisms get activated to match the lower setpoint. It includes vasodilatation of the skin's blood vessel, sweating, and decreased thermogenesis.

questions.text: A buried skeleton was brought to the forensic laboratory. Age estimation was carried out. With respect to the carpal bones shown below, which among them are the first and last bones to ossify, respectively?
questions.solution:
The capitate (marked as 5) is the first one to ossify and the pisiform (marked as 3) is the last carpal bone to ossify.

Order of ossification centers of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 1-3 months
  • Hamate: 2-4 months
  • Triquetrum: 2-3 years
  • Lunate: 2-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 4-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 4-6 years
  • Pisiform: 8-12 years

At the end of 1 year, 2 carpal bones are seen in the x-ray of the wrist. Between 2 to 6 years the number of carpal bones present on x-ray indicates the approximate age in years. 

The capitate is the central and largest carpal bone. It articulates with the following:

  • 2nd, 3rd and 4th metacarpal
  • Lunate and scaphoid in the proximal row 
  • Trapezoid and hamate in the distal row

Pisiform articulates with triquetrum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility. The sonogram of both her ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentartion causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

Classification of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Grade I Abdominal discomfort or distension
Grade II

Abdominal discomfort or distension + nausea and vomiting or diarrhea+ Enlarged ovaries (5-12 cm)
Grade III Ultrasonographic evidence of ascites
Grade IV Clinical evidence of ascites/hydrothorax/breathing difficulty
Grade V All of the above with decreased blood volume, hemoconcentration, diminished renal perfusion and function, and coagulation abnormalities. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

Sonographic criteria for PCOS include:

  • >/= 20 small cysts ( 2 to 9 mm diameter) or,
  • Increased ovarian volume (>10 mL), or both

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They typically occur after the first trimester due to luteinization of the follicular theca luteal layer in response to exceptionally high HCG. They are commonly seen in:

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Multiple gestational preganancy
  • Fetal hydrops
  • Placentaomegaly

Ultrasonography shows a "spoke wheel pattern". Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.

 


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus. Depending on the level of genital blockage, blood can distend:

  • Vagina called hematocolpos
  • Uterus called hematometra
  • Fallopian tubes called hematosalpinx

Patients usually present with cyclic midline pain, low backache, amenorrhea, and pelvic fullness. A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

Ultrasonography is the diagnostic tool that shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity. Relieving the obstruction and evacuation of blood is the primary management.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency following a road traffic accident. He is intoxicated and his blood alcohol level is high.  Examination revealed a fractured femur. He is posted for surgery. When compared to that in a person who is not intoxicated with alcohol, the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of sevoflurane in this patient is expected to be __________ .
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes acute alcohol intoxication in which the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of sevoflurane will be reduced when compared to a patient who is not intoxicated with alcohol.

The MAC of an inhaled anesthetic is the minimum alveolar concentration that prevents patient movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus like a surgical incision.

  Sympatholytics like methyldopa, clonidine, dexmedetomidine
 
Younger age (maximum at 6 months of age)

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese woman comes to the clinic with complaints of multiple painful lesions associated with a foul-smelling discharge in the axilla. Examination findings are as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple lesions with foul-smelling discharge in the intertriginous area (axilla) in an obese female is strongly suggestive of hidradenitis suppurativa.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is also called acne inversa and is seen more commonly seen after puberty. It is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - The lesions can manifest as deep‐seated painful nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudo comedones.
  2. Typical locations - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks, and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

Treatment includes: 

  • General measures - lifestyle modifications such as cessation of smoking, weight loss, and general cleanliness are advised. 
  • Antibiotics - Topical clindamycin lotion 0.1% can be used to manage milder lesions. Systemic antibiotics like tetracycline and a combination of clindamycin and rifampicin can be used in such conditions.
  • Intralesional corticosteroids such a triaminolone can be used.
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery - Many lesion‐directed therapies have been identified as beneficial in the therapy of HS. Incision and drainage are done in a presence of a fluctuant abscess. Deroofing can also be done which is a tissue-saving procedure in which the roof of an abscess or sinus tract is surgically removed using either electrosurgery (using a loop) or conventional surgery. Ablative lasers and electrosurgery are also useful in removing all the involved tissues. 

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris is one of the most common skin diseases, highly prevalent in adolescents. The lesions can manifest as open and closed comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules with variable degrees of inflammation and depth. The most usually affected areas are the face, back, and/or chest. These would not be found in the axillary region.

Option B: Necrobiosis lipoidica can happen at any age, it typically is seen in young adults and those in their early middle years. It is associated with diabetes. The lesion starts as a hard, dull red papule or plaque on the pretibial skin and enlarges radially to become a yellowish atrophic plaque with an erythematous edge. Telangiectatic vessels may be seen, and the surface is frequently glazed in appearance.

Option C: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare non‐infectious neutrophilic dermatosis. It is commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The major criteria to diagnosis classical PG are a rapid progression of a painful, necrolytic cutaneous ulcer with an irregular, violaceous, and undermined border; and the elimination of any other causes of cutaneous ulceration. These lesions are usually not found in the axilla.

questions.text:
Match the pictures with the corresponding plant poison.

A - Ricinus communis 

B - Atropa belladonna

C - Calotropis gigantea

D - Digitalis purpurea
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is given in option A: 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B.

In the given image: 

  • 1- Digitalis purpurea (Foxglove)
  • 2- Calotropis gigantea
  • 3- Ricinus communis (castor bean)
  • 4- Atropa belladonna (belladonna or deadly nightshade)

Digitalis purpurea is also known as 'foxglove'. Digitalis is a cardioactive steroid that acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump. Acute toxicity closely resembles that of digoxin and includes early GI symptoms followed by cardiac dysrhythmias. 

Calotropis gigantea is identified by the presence of purple or white flowers. The active principles include uscharin, calotoxin, calactin and calotropin (glycoside). It is an organic irritant. It acts as an abortifacient when applied locally. On external application, it produces an artificial bruise. When ingested, it acts as a gastrointestinal and cerebrospinal poison (not cardiac poison).

Ricinus communis is identified by rose-red softly spiny fruits. The entire plant is poisonous but the seeds are the most poisonous. The poisonous component is toxalbumin ricin. It is a glycoprotein that blocks protein synthesis. The seeds contain the highest level of ricin. The fatal dose is 5 to 10 seeds or 50-100µ ricin.

Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death

Atropa belladonna- All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine. It acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

Clinical manifestations include anticholinergic symptoms such as tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis, and urinary retention. Agitation and delirium are the most serious problems in such patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents with complaints of foggy vision. He mentions that he cannot read newspapers. He is a heavy tobacco smoker for the past 30 years. Examination revealed a centrocecal scotoma. What is the most important step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy. Complete abstinence from smoking is the most important step in management in this case.

Tobacco-induced optic neuropathy (previously termed toxic amblyopia) is caused by excessive use of tobacco by smoking and chewing. The toxic agent involved is cyanide found in tobacco.

The illustration given below shows the pathogenesis of tobacco-induced optic neuropathy.

It is characterized by bilateral gradually progressive impairment of central vision, and a centrocecal scotoma - a type of central scotoma involving both the blind spot and macula. Fundus examination may be normal or slight temporal pallor of the disc may be seen.

Treatment includes

  • Complete cessation of tobacco and alcohol consumption.
  • Improvement may be hastened by hydroxocobalamin 1000 μg intramuscular injections weekly for 10 weeks. Though intramuscular vitamin B12 injection may hasten the recovery, eliminating the causative factor i.e. tobacco cessation should be the mainstay of treatment. 
  • Nutritional supplements.

Causes of central/centrocecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
    • Poor nutrition
    • Tobacco
    • Alcohol
  • Drug-induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin-induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: Which among the following skin conditions is correctly matched with its appearance under the Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas pyocyanea appears yellowish-green under the Wood's lamp examination.

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: The median weight of 100 children was 12 kg, and it showed a normal distribution. The standard deviation was 3. Calculate the percentage of the coefficient of variation.
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution, mean = median.

Coefficient of variation, CV = standard deviation x 100/ mean. 

In this scenario, CV = 3 x 100/12 = 25%.
