questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past week. There is no rash. His symptoms began after returning from visiting his daughter in South Carolina, USA. Laboratory investigations reveal leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows intracellular inclusions in monocytes, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows morula, an intracellular inclusion body in a monocyte. This finding along with the clinical vignette and history of travel to the southeastern United States is strongly suggestive of human monocytic ehrlichiosis caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis. 

E. chaffeensis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria that are transmitted by hard ticks such as the Lone star tick. 

Clinically, the symptom onset is typically within one to three weeks of exposure. Patients may present with fever, headache, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and weight loss. Rashes are generally absent. Severe human monocytic ehrlichiosis is characterized by meningoencephalitis, renal failure, respiratory failure, and shock. 

Diagnosis is by demonstration of the characteristic morulae in the mononuclear cells such as monocytes. They are intracellular inclusions formed due to the replication of these bacteria within clustered phagocytic vacuoles. Serological studies such as indirect fluorescent antibody tests and detection using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can also be used. 

The treatment of choice for human monocytic ehrlichiosis is doxycycline. 

Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum and the presence of tetrads (Maltese crosses), which are pathognomic of Babesia microti or Babesia duncani.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The x-ray given in the question shows the double-density sign, which is suggestive of left atrial enlargement. Pulmonary stenosis is not associated with left atrial enlargement.

A double-density sign is seen due to left atrial enlargement, the right border of the left atrium becomes laterally displaced and convex producing this appearance.

The causes of left atrial enlargement are:

Acquired Congenital

Mitral regurgitation

Mitral stenosis

Aortic stenosis

Left ventricular failure

Left atrial myxoma

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)


Signs of left atrial enlargement:

  • The convex contour of the left atrial appendage - normally it is concave in appearance. 
  • Double density sign 
  • In left atrial enlargement, the distance from the midportion of the double-density sign to the middle of the left main bronchus is more than 7cm.
  • Prominent posterosuperior part of the cardiac shadow.
  • Elevation of left main bronchus and widening of the carina on PA view.

questions.text: An autopsy is done on a plastic factory worker. The gross specimen of the liver is shown in the image below. Reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) are present. The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue. Which of the following compounds is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of the involved tumor?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) which are seen with hepatic angiosarcoma. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and thorotrast can lead to this condition.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens.

Examples of carcinogenic agents:

  • Arsenic - in pesticides
  • Thorotrast - a radioactive contrast agent formerly used for radiologic imaging
  • Polyvinyl chloride - a widely used plastic

Carcinoma

Carcinogens

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Cholangiocarcinoma

Thorotrast

Angiosarcoma

Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, Arsenic

The given histopathological image shows abundant small blood vessels lined by large atypical endothelial cells and atypical mitoses seen in angiosarcoma. The endothelial origin of these tumors can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical staining for CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Choose the option in which the enzyme and its function are incorrectly matched.

choices.text: DNA polymerase - involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization
Helicase - prevents premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA
Topoisomerase - relieves torsional strain caused by unwinding of DNA
DNA ligase - sealing nicks in DNA strands

questions.solution:
Helicase is not involved in the prevention of premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA (dsDNA); this is the function of single-strand binding proteins (SSBs)

Helicases belong to a class of proteins involved in DNA replication. They are involved in ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options:

Option B- Topoisomerases - Relieve torsional strain resulting from unwinding

Option D- DNA ligase - Seals nicks in the DNA strand during replication

questions.text: A 16-year-old athlete who had a mutation in the gene encoding for myosin-binding protein C was brought dead to casualty.  Which among the following is the most likely histopathological feature seen in the above condition?

choices.text: Diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and mutation in the gene encoding for myosin-binding protein C are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The most likely histological feature in this condition is the haphazard disarray of myocytes or myofiber disarray.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy and reduced function of the left ventricular myocardium leading to abnormal diastolic function.

The most common mutation of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is in the genes encoding for myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) or beta myosin heavy chain. Other mutation includes genes encoding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and alpha tropomyosin. While most patients are asymptomatic some of them may develop symptoms like dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation. HCM is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. 

Massive myocardial dilatation without ventricular dilatation is an essential feature of HCM. Most of the cases have a disproportionate thickening of the ventricular septum termed asymmetric septal hypertrophy is the classical pattern observed in HCM. Due to the bulging of the ventricular septum into the lumen, the normal round-to-ovoid left ventricular cavity may be compressed into a banana-like configuration.

The most important histologic feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy, with transverse myocytes size greater than 40 µm (normal size approximately 15 µm) 
  • Haphazard disarray of bundles of, individual myocytes, and contractile elements termed as myofiber disarray
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The image given below is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and extreme hypertrophy:

Other options:

Option A: Contraction band necrosis can be seen in reperfusion injury after myocardial infarction (MI). It is also a histological feature seen in takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Histology showing irreversibly injured myocytes with contraction band necrosis and intensely eosinophilic bands of hypercontracted sarcomeres is shown below.

Option C: Ninja star nuclei in myocytes are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

Option D: Biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue is suggestive of myocarditis. Viruses are the most common causes among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown below.

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Missense mutation
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin
  • Myofibre disarray on histology
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:
    1. Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient came with complaints of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. The urine pregnancy test was positive. Her thyroid profile is given below. She reports that her mother has Graves disease. What is the drug of choice for her present condition?

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) - decreased

T4 - increased
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of hyperthyroidism in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. Propylthiouracil is the drug of choice for this patient. 

Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It inhibits the peroxidase enzyme, which catalyzes the coupling reaction of iodotyrosyl residues; thus reducing thyroid hormone synthesis. Propylthiouracil also inhibits peripheral iodothyronine deiodination.

Uses:

  • As a definitive treatment and to control remission in Graves disease
  • In conjunction with radioactive iodine
  • Preoperatively to control the disorder requiring surgery

Adverse effects:

  • Agranulocytosis is reversible once the drug is stopped
  • Most common is urticarial rash
  • Teratogenic potential limited to methimazole and carbimazole leading to
    • Fetal aplasia cutis 
    • Choanal and esophageal atresia

Propylthiouracil does not cross the placental barrier whereas methimazole and carbimazole cross the placental barrier leading to teratogenicity. Therefore, propylthiouracil is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism in 1st trimester of pregnancy (period of organogenesis). Propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity, following which it is replaced with methimazole (or carbimazole) in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

Other options:

Option D: Levothyroxine is a thyroid hormone preparation used in the treatment of hypothyroidism and myxedema coma.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

questions.text: A child presents with perianal itching, which occurs predominantly at night and disturbs sleep. The eggs of the causative organism have been shown in the given image. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection.

Infection with Enterobius vermicularis presents with perianal itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus).

Plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo, are deposited by the gravid female worm on perianal skin which causes pruritis.

Diagnosis: 

  • Microscopic examination of adhesive cellophane tape pressed against the perianal region early in the morning frequently demonstrates eggs.
  • A digital rectal examination may also be used to obtain samples for a wet mount.
  • Routine stool samples rarely demonstrate Enterobius ova.

Treatment: 

  • Albendazole 400 mg PO with a repeat dose 2 weeks
  • Frequent changing of underclothes, bedclothes, and bedsheets decreases environmental egg contamination and may decrease the risk for autoinfection.
  • Good hand hygiene is the most effective method of prevention.
The image given below shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect regarding ROME IV criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent abdominal pain, on average should be present for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months
Associated with a change in stool form
Associated with a change in stool frequency
Abdominal pain for the last 3 weeks with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:

  • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
  • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant
  • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet
  • Fecal calprotectin levels help distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from IBS

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: A gastrointestinal smooth muscle was being studied. It was then subjected to electrical and mechanical recording. A trace of the recordings obtained is given below. What is the effect of acetylcholine and epinephrine on the number of spikes, respectively?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine increases and epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and the tension of the gastrointestinal smooth muscle.

The smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract have a basal electrical rhythm. The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65 mV and -45 mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese smoker presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, multiple purple striae are noticed over the abdomen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test.
Raised late night salivary cortisol level is used for diagnosis.
Overnight 100-mg dexamethasone-suppression test is used for diagnosis.
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability with multiple purple striae over the abdomen is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. 24-h urine-free cortisol level is raised and is a cost-effective screening test.

Cushing syndrome is characterized by prolonged exposure to high circulating levels of cortisol, i.e., hypercortisolism, which can be due to endogenous or exogenous causes. 

Endogenous hypercortisolism can be ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is termed Cushing's disease. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism can also be caused by ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. ACTH-independent hypercortisolism is mainly caused by adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, and carcinoma.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing. 

24-h urine-free cortisol (UFC) can detect endogenous overproduction of cortisol and is used as a screening test. An overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test (Option C) can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism.

Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease. But, in smokers, late-night salivary cortisol can be falsely high (Option B) due to the inhibition of 11-beta-hydroxy dehydrogenase on the salivary gland, and hence it is not confirmatory. 

Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  

  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about 50% are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Tapering exogenous steroids is the best therapy for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. The treatment of choice for Cushing's disease is selective transsphenoidal resection, and radiotherapy can be used in failed transsphenoidal surgery.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast-enhanced MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to the excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. This syndrome is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. The excess serotonin produced is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA.  

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman was brought with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she drinks 2-3 beers a day and that she had taken excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus. The vitals and results of laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Vitals and laboratory investigations:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 85 beats/min
  • Temp: 98.7 F
  • Hb: 11.3 g/dL
  • MCV: 110 fL
  • Fingerstick glucose (GRBS): 64 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with confusion, agitation, and horizontal nystagmus. This clinical history along with the recent history of heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Chronic alcoholics have thiamine (B1) deficiency, which gets exacerbated with recent excessive intake.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :
    • Global confusion
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Horizontal nystagmus 
  • Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:
    • Memory loss
    • Confabulation
  • Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Hence, the initial treatment in a patient with high alcohol intake with new-onset ataxia should be emergent IV thiamine infusion to prevent the progression of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other Options:

Option B- IV glucose: It should be given after IV thiamine in an alcoholic patient to treat hypoglycemia. Because if given before, it will worsen thiamine deficiency and will deteriorate this patient's condition.

Option C- IV naltrexone: It is given to abstain from alcohol use, not for treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy

Option D- IV vitamin B12: Although this patient has macrocytosis and difficulty walking, nystagmus is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence, it is not given. Macrocytosis in this patient is due to chronic alcohol use.

questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin has substantial activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can be used in this patient.

Mild-to-moderate respiratory exacerbations owing to P. aeruginosa in patients with cystic fibrosis respond to oral ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin therapy.

Activity against streptococci is significantly greater with newer quinolones like levofloxacin, gemifloxacin, and moxifloxacin.

Other options:

Option B: Gemifloxacin is a broad-spectrum fluoroquinolone active against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumophila, and Klebsiella.

Option C: Moxifloxacin has clinically significant activity against anaerobes including Bacteroides fragilis. It is reported to have similar efficacy to piperacillin-tazobactam for complicated intra-abdominal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is related to the triangle shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Passaro’s triangle, which is related to gastrinomas. Around 90% of gastrinomas are found within this triangle. 

The three points forming this triangle are the junction of the cystic duct and the common bile duct, the junction of the second and third portion of the duodenum, and the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 (MEN-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Other options:

Option (A): Insulinomas are insulin-secreting tumors of the pancreas that cause hypoglycemia. They are found either in the pancreas or attached directly to it. They are not found specifically within this kind of anatomical triangle. 

Option (B): Glucagonoma should be suspected when a patient has diabetes associated with dermatitis. Necrolytic migratory erythema is one of the classical skin manifestations seen in these patients. These tumors are found in the body and tail of the pancreas.

Option (D): Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor (VIPoma) is also called watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome. It is a tumor that is most commonly found in the distal pancreas.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: An HIV-positive male patient is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. The consultant adds emtricitabine, a drug with dual antiviral activity, to his treatment card. This drug belongs to which of the following classes of antiviral agents?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and hepatitis B viruses (HBV).

Emtricitabine is an FDA-approved drug for treating HIV infection in adults, children, and infants, in combination with other antiretroviral agents. It is also approved for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with tenofovir) in adults with a high risk of acquiring the infection.

It has good oral absorption and can be taken without regard to meals. It is excreted unchanged in the urine and the dose should be reduced in patients with poor renal function.

Emtricitabine is one of the least toxic antiviral drugs. Prolonged exposure can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, especially in sun-exposed areas. It should not be abruptly discontinued in HBV patients as it can lead to a rebound of HBV replication and exacerbation of hepatitis.

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

questions.text: A primigravida with an adequate pelvis and good contractions goes into active labor. You notice the hand alongside the fetal head as shown below. What should be the immediate next step of management?

choices.text: Gently reposition the hand inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT

questions.solution:
The given scenario of the presentation of the hand alongside the fetal head is suggestive of a compound presentation. Expectant management with observation alone is sufficient.

Contracted pelvis, fetal prematurity, polyhydramnios, and multifetal gestations predispose to this presentation. The most common compound presentation is a hand prolapsing alongside the head.

In most cases, expectant management is enough. With the progression of labour, the prolapsed hand retracts with the descent of the fetal head. If retraction fails and the hand seems to be blocking the head, the prolapsed arm is gently pushed upward and fundal pressure is applied to promote the descent of the head.

If cord prolapse is present or the pelvis is contracted, a caesarean section should be done.

questions.text: The contraceptive shown in the image contains _______.
questions.solution:
The contraceptive shown in the image is today which is a mushroom shaped polyurethane disposal sponge that contains nonoxynol 9.

Today is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane disposal sponge of dimensions 2 inches in diameter, and 1.25 inches in thickness containing 1 g of nonoxynol-9. 

It should be placed high up in the vagina with the concave side covering the cervix. It is for single-time use which can remain effective for 24 hours. It acts as a mechanical barrier and prevents entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs semen and contains a spermicidal agent. It is provided with a loop for easy removal.

Failure rate: 9-30 per 100 women years. Disadvantages are it is coitus-dependant and costly. If left for a longer period of time, the chances of occurrence of toxic shock syndrome are high.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant was brought by the mother due to abnormal eye movements and developmental delay. MRI findings are shown in the image given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the axial T1-weighted MRI image showing the molar tooth sign at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles is suggestive of Joubert syndrome.

The molar tooth sign is a cardinal feature of the Joubert malformation. It is created by a combination of midbrain hypoplasia, along with an abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and a failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.

Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurologic disorder. It is characterized by cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. It is associated with hypotonia, developmental delay, ataxia, irregular breathing pattern, and abnormal eye movements.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presented with hemoptysis and reduced urine output. There is no history of asthma or upper airway disease. On evaluation, he is found to be positive for p-ANCA. Renal biopsy showed non-granulomatous inflammation, with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is microscopic polyangiitis.

The above clinical scenario of hemoptysis, reduced urine output, positive p-ANCA antibody, and biopsy showing non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with few or no immune complexes affecting the small vessels (capillaries, venules, and arterioles). It may have a gradual or acute onset associated with fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis which results in renal failure. Hemoptysis occurs due to alveolar hemorrhage.

Laboratory investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. Most cases are associated with positive p-ANCA antibodies. Tissue biopsy would reveal non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Patients with PAN do not show p-ANCA and c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation associated with luminal thrombosis.

Options B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. These patients show c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. You would suspect that it was most likely shot at a distance range of ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun which can be seen from 1 to 5 meters of range.

Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 30 cm to 1 m range.

Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 1 m to 5 m range.

The rat-hole appearance of the entry wound:

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

  • Soft tissues - single circular wound about the diameter of the muzzle with muzzle imprint and no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.
  • Bone - same as with soft tissues, but wound may be ragged and split because of gas rebound.

<30 cm

  • Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling.
  • Burnt hairs (singeing).
  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

30cm - 1m

  • Circular rat-hole wound.
  • Soot soiling.
  • Powder tattooing.

1 - 5 meters

  • Central rat-hole wound.
  • No soot, tattooing +/-.
  • Satellite pellet holes around the periphery.

>5 meters

  • Diffuse pellet pattern
  • No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the OPD with redness of the eye. The examination findings of her eye are shown in the image below. She had been previously diagnosed with glaucoma and was receiving a topical drug. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows conjunctival hyperemia. It is the side effect of apraclonidine. It occurs due to an allergic response to apraclonidine. 

Apraclonidine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist. It is used in the treatment of ocular hypertension and glaucoma. It is available as a topical preparation of 0.5 and 1% solutions.

The notable side effects of apraclonidine include conjunctival hyperemia, sleepiness, and dry mouth. 

Prostaglandin analogs like latanoprost and bimatoprost can also be associated with conjunctival hyperemia.

Other options:

Option A: Pilocarpine is associated with side effects that include corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia associated with decreased vision, brow ache, and retinal detachment

Option B: Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, and impotence.

Option C: Echothiophate is associated with retinal detachment, miosis, cataract, pupillary block, glaucoma, iris cysts, brow ache, and punctal stenosis, which may further result in epiphora.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy diagnosed with tonsillitis complains of referred pain in the ears. Which of the following nerves is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

Image below shows the anatomic relations of tonsil and tonsillar bed.

The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3).

Jacobson's nerve along with branches from the sympathetic plexus forms the tympanic plexus. This plexus provides sensation to the middle ear, upper eustachian tube, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane.

Referred otalgia transmitted by the glossopharyngeal nerve may be secondary to lesions and/or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate, or posterior one-third of the tongue.

Causes of referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Acute pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Post-tonsillectomy
  • Foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area
  • Elongated styloid process

questions.text: The given image shows the x-ray findings of a patient with osteitis deformans. In which phase of the disease are these findings seen?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a blade of grass/ flame-shaped lesion on the x-ray. It is seen in the osteolytic phase of osteitis deformans.

Osteitis deformans is also called Paget's disease of the bone. It is a chronic disease of increased bone turnover in localized areas, resulting in enlarged and thickened bones. There is a significant increase in osteoclastic and osteoblastic activity.

It is usually asymptomatic but can present with dull aching pain unless the disease is severe. Bowing of leg bones may occur. There is an increased risk of pathological fractures and osteosarcoma. 

Paget's disease of the bone is divided into 3 phases:

Phases Pathophysiology X-ray findings
Osteolytic phase Bone resorption and marked hypervascularization An advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.
Mixed phase Very active bone formation and resorption that replaces normal lamellar bone with haphazard (woven) bone.
  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Ivory vertebra
  • Cotton wool skull
Sclerotic phase

Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

 Tam o' Shanter skull/diploic swelling (thickening of the skull)

Serum alkaline phosphate levels may be raised or maybe normal. Treatment is done using intravenous zoledronate given as a single infusion of 4–5 mg.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought by his mother with complaints of low-grade fever and the following rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic 'slapped cheek appearance' seen in erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19.

It evolves in three phases:

  1. First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks, (slapped cheek). Prodromal symptoms may or may not be present.
  2. Second phase -  begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk.
  3. Third phase - Recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

Only about 7% of children with erythema infectiosum have arthralgias, whereas 80% of adults have joint involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen due to an injury to Meyer’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop (or) Archambault’s loop.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.
